「Qiu Ye could be the steward for a household of a hundred chariots,
and You could govern a thousand-chariot state by managing its taxes.

From this, one may observe that the teachings of this book
are also based on the magnitude of the responsibilities entrusted.

*The Zhuangzi* says:
*"When the assignment of duties is clear, then the examination of their origins and principles follows.
Only when duties are properly assigned can one examine their origins."*

Thus, it is said:
The **virtue/power** of the benevolent,
is that they do good without striving for gain,
and those below do not resent those above.

The **virtue/power** of the eloquent,
is that they resolve grievances and untangle disputes.

The **virtue/power** of the wise,
is that they address matters as they arise,
and respond to difficulties with appropriate measures.

The **virtue/power** of the loyal subject,
is that they speak truthfully and act uprightly,
correcting the ruler’s errors with firmness.

The **virtue/power** of the righteous subject,
is that they preserve the living and continue the extinct,
and rescue the weak while punishing the violent.

The **virtue/power** of the trustworthy subject,
is that they affirm what is right without wavering in speech.

The **virtue/power** of the upright and modest,
is that they discard personal interests and uphold the public good.

*The Han Feizi* says:
*"Self-promotion is the way of the petty,
while abandoning private interests for the public is the way of the noble."*

The **virtue/power** of the ritualist,
is that they honor the ruler’s carriage and attendants.

The **virtue/power** of the worthy,
is that enemy states fear them,
and the four borders remain unbreached.

The **virtue/power** of the sage,
is that they establish laws in the unseen,
achieve what they seek and obtain what they desire,
are obeyed without question,
draw near and distant alike,
and their wisdom shines in all four directions.
From this up to the unseen,
the responsibility of the sage is clear.

Within, they hold fast to their principles,
using them as a measure for verification—
this is what is meant by **"Dao/Way" as a guiding standard**.

Then comes the ability to judge by a single root or principle,
and to assess people with two words.

Without inner restraint,
one cannot discern the things they observe.
A wealthy man’s generosity reveals his **virtue/power of benevolence**.
A noble man’s promotions reveal his loyalty.

Observe their **great conduct**—
whether they defer to the young or the old,
whether the noble defer to the lowly—
this reveals their sense of **ritual/propriety**.

Observe what they refuse to do,
and this reveals their **righteousness/principle**.

Observe their acceptance of office and governance,
and their decisions to leave or stay—
this reveals their **insight/wisdom**.

Observe whether they are unyielding when pressed,
and this reveals their **courage**.

Observe whether their speech is sharp and their words skillful,
and this reveals their **eloquence**.

Observe whether they do not conceal when entrusted,
and this reveals their **trustworthiness**.

Observe what a poor man refuses to take,
and this reveals their **cleanliness/integrity**.
Observe what a lowly man refuses to do,
and this reveals their **worthiness**.

Measure their depth and observe their Heavenly alignment,
and this reveals their **sageliness**.

The essentials of assigning duties and examining origins
lie in knowing people,
and knowing people lies in having a way to observe them.

Confucius said:
*"Observe the way they act,
consider the circumstances that lead them there,
and examine where they find rest—
how could one fail to know them?"*

Thus, this is further elaborated upon:
The ranks are never misaligned,
and the principles do not contradict each other.

Near and distant are harmonized,
and the prepared are vigilant against change—
*"Prepared"* is how they avoid being constrained,
*"Vigilant"* is how they do not grow weary from adapting.

They understand their duties and act accordingly,
measuring affairs with their own principles.

A ruler without the **Dao/Way** employs the **petty and unworthy**—
the petty and unworthy are those of little virtue,
whose opposite is **noble and strong**—
and their actions bring only confusion and disorder.

A ruler with the **Dao/Way** employs the **noble and strong**,
and their actions are clear and harmonious.

These two principles, once established,
are like the **Mingqi**—
the **Mingtai** below, the **Mingqi** above.

*"Mingqi"* refers to the **sacred vessel**,
and *"Mingtai"* refers to the **spiritual platform**.
*"Sympathy"* and *"verification"* are complementary.

The ruler aligns with their **virtue/power** above,
and the subjects confirm its truth below.

The **ruler’s timing**—
some texts say *"ruler’s intentions"*—
awaits the moment to act.

When the **ruler’s timing** is clear,
they respond to the **Dao/Way** and issue commands.

The worthy in their domains,
though different in nature,
share a common understanding of **timing and circumstances**.

The **ruler’s timing**—
originally *"timing and circumstances"*—
when encountering a person of **virtue/power**,
they do not need to speak to be trusted,
and all the people naturally turn to them in kinship.

When encountering a violent and arrogant person,
the people scatter and flee.
Above and below grow suspicious of each other,
and their conflicts spiral like an unbroken ring,
day and night without end.

Those who offer counsel are not heeded,
those who speak are placed in danger,
and there is no way to hear of mistakes—
thus, great ministers feign loyalty but are not truly so.

Therefore, a ruler who loves their people like a father
does not need to summon them;
this is the effect of the **sacred platform**.

Thus, they shine with **light/clarity**,
and their reputation ends in splendor.

If they punish without first instructing,
or love while demanding closeness—
some texts say *"love while seeking intimacy"*—
then they invite **calamity**,
and their end is in misfortune.

When the worthy serve their ruler,
they adjust and harmonize—
some texts say *"know and unite"*—
their **Dao/Way** is pure and steadfast,
like the **unyielding**—
some texts say *"fortified"*—
**worthy subjects** who act with restraint.

They lead and transform them,
and the world follows in approval.
Their **Dao/Way** grows ever more aligned,
and thus their end is certain to flourish.

When the petty serve their ruler,
they strive to obscure their ruler’s clarity,
block their hearing,
exploit their authority,
and make people cold or hot with their schemes—
some texts say *"create discord"*—
relying on the ruler’s power,
they manipulate others’ comfort.

The world despises them,
and their rise is marked by ruin—
some texts say *"their height is ominous"*—
thus their end is certain to fail,
and their misfortune extends to their kin.

This is the transformation between ruler and subject,
the distinction between order and chaos,
the key to the rise and fall of states,
and the critical juncture for a nation’s fate.

*"Critical juncture"* can also mean *"warning"* or *"checkpoint"*.
The path of **reversal and compliance**, **benefit and harm**, arises from here.

In general, what can be done without study or learning,
is only **breathing and eating**.

Thus, the ancient kings passed down the **Dao/Way**—
some texts say *"broadened the Dao/Way"*—
the ancient kings, or alternatively *"the first teachers"*,

to emulate and inherit.

Worthy rulers follow established laws,
and their legacy endures for generations.
Unworthy rulers do not comply,
and their dynasty perishes in their own time.

The laws of **Yu** still exist,
yet the **Xia** never became a perpetual dynasty—
this is why.

Nearly the same as *"repeatedly"*—
some texts say *"seventh"*—

Pang Zi asked the **Lu Guan Zi**:
*"What does the sage’s **Dao/Way** prioritize?"*

The **Lu Guan Zi** replied:
*"Prioritizing people."*

Pang Zi asked:
*"What does the **Dao/Way of people** prioritize?"*

The **Lu Guan Zi** replied:
*"Prioritizing arms."*

Pang Zi asked:
*"Why abandon Heaven and prioritize people?"*

The **Lu Guan Zi** replied:
*"Heaven is vast and difficult to know,
its blessings cannot be requested,
and its calamities cannot be avoided.
To model oneself after Heaven is to oppose the **Dao/Way**."*

chunks.original_text: 地广大深厚，多利一作则而鲜威， 天尊而不亲，地亲不不尊。 法地则辱； 时举错代更无一，法时则贰。 三者不可以立化树俗，故圣人弗法。 庞子曰：阴阳何若？ 鹖冠子曰：神灵威明与天合， 神之精明实灵。 勾萌动作与地俱， 屈生日勾。 阴阳寒暑与时至，三者圣人存则治、亡则乱，是故先人。 富则骄，贵则羸。 兵者，百岁不一用，然不可一日忘也，是故人道先兵。 庞子曰：先兵奈何？ 鹖冠子曰：兵者，礼、义、忠、信也。 庞子曰：愿闻兵义。 鹖冠子曰：失道，故敢以贱逆贵； 不义，故敢以小侵大。 庞子曰：用之奈何？ 州鹖冠子曰：行枉耻禁，反正则舍，是故不杀降人。 鹰不击伏，况於人乎？ 主道所高，莫贵约束； 得地失信，圣王弗据； 倍言负约，各将有故。

The Earth is vast and profound,
its benefits are many—*or, its use is broad*—yet its punishments are few,
Heaven is exalted yet distant,
Earth is near yet not unexalted.
To model oneself after Earth is to bring shame;

**Time** arises, shifts, and changes without pause—
to model oneself after **Time** is to falter.
These three cannot be relied upon to establish **Dao/Way** or shape customs,
thus the sage does not follow them.

Pang Zi asked:
*"What of **Yin** and **Yang**?"*

The **Lu Guan Zi** replied:
*"Their **spiritual vitality** and luminous clarity align with Heaven,
their **spiritual essence** is truly responsive.
**Yin**’s latent stirrings act in concert with Earth,
**Yang**’s daily arc **Yin** follows.
**Yin** and **Yang**’s cold and heat, along with **Time**’s shifts,
these three: when the sage preserves them, order ensues;
when they perish, chaos reigns—
thus, he prioritizes people.

Wealth brings arrogance,
honor brings decay.
War is a tool not employed every hundred years,
yet one cannot forget it for a single day—
this is why the **Dao/Way of people** prioritizes arms.

Pang Zi asked:
*"How does one prioritize arms?"*

The **Lu Guan Zi** replied:
*"Arms are the embodiment of **ritual propriety (礼)**, **rightness (义)**, **loyalty (忠)**, and **trustworthiness (信)**."*

Pang Zi asked:
*"I wish to hear the **Dao/Way of arms**."*

The **Lu Guan Zi** replied:
*"Without **Dao/Way**, one dares to defy the noble with the base;
without **rightness (义)**, one dares to encroach upon the great with the small.
When one acts unjustly, **shame and restraint (枉耻禁)** are enforced;
when one returns to correctness, the punishment is abandoned—
thus, one does not slay those who surrender.
A hawk does not strike a fallen bird—how much more so with people?
The highest **Dao/Way** esteems **ritual propriety (礼)**,
nothing is more noble than **restraint (约束)**.
To gain land yet lose **trustworthiness (信)**, even a **sage-king (圣王)** would not rely upon it;
to double one’s words and break one’s **pledges (约)**, each will have their own reasons."*

Pang Zi said:
*"My disciples have heard that: ‘The larger the land, the stronger the state; the more numerous the people, the mightier the army; the mightier the army, the sooner one attains one’s ambitions in the world.’
But now, the armies of great states retreat in disgrace and their words are exhausted—**shame and restraint (枉耻禁)** fail to control them, and orders cannot be enforced. Why is this so?
Orders command what should be done; prohibitions forbid what should not be done.

The **Lu Guan Zi** replied:
*"To know what will come, examine what has passed;
to know the ancient, observe the present.
The ruler who **selects (择) people** and then **employs (用) them** will thrive; the ruler who **employs people** without first **selecting (择) them** will perish.
When **rebellious conduct (逆节)** arises, the unworthy encroach upon the virtuous—**daily (日) oppressing (凌)** them;
when **the low oppress (凌) the high**, it is called **victory (胜)**.
**The high overpower (胜) the low**—this is the way of things.
Now, the question you ask, my friend, **be cautious not to speak of it (子慎勿言)**.

When a state’s land is vast and its people numerous, its army is strong—this is called **sufficiency (足)**.
But if its scholars have **excessive strength (余力)** yet cannot **attain their ambitions in the world (先得志於天下)**, then its ruler is **not virtuous (不贤)** and **acts with arrogance and constraint (骄缢)**.
To **be self-exalted (己亢)** is arrogance; to **be self-satisfied (己满)** is excess.
If a ruler is **not virtuous (不贤)**, he cannot **avoid action (无为)**, nor can he **be trusted to act together (与致为)** with others.
Mencius said: ‘There are things a man **will not do (不为)**, and only then can he **do what is proper (有为)**.’
When one is arrogant, he **despises his enemy (轻敌)**;
when he despises his enemy, he **plots with those he favors (所私谋)**, acting against what he does not know.
He **assigns tasks beyond their strength (非其任力)**, seeking **victory over those not his true enemy (非其敌)**,
without considering the **long-term calamities (终身之患)** of his state,
but instead delighting in **temporary success (须臾之说)**.
Thus, the ruler **suffers slander from his subjects (被过听之谤)** and is **held in contempt by the world (丑於天下)**,
while his ministers **bear false accusations (负滥监)**.
The **blame is directed at enemy states (首之责于敌国)**;
when enemy states **lay the blame upon him (乃责则却)**, they **retreat or are plundered (却或作劫)**,
using **words to evade (以辞那之)**.
If they **retreat (却)**, the speaker is **shamed by his weakness (说者羞其弱)**;
if they **evade with words (以辞却之)**, then the speaker **is shamed by his weakness (则说)**,
while those who **lay the blame (责之者)** are **shamed by his weakness (羞其弱)**—
this **leads to the exhaustion of their strength (其势铃)** until they **must resort to arms (至於用兵)**.
A thousand **base (万贱)** may not **straighten (挠)** one **noble (贵)** who **bows (曲)**;
and those **below (在下者)** have **no means to counter (回)** them."

chunks.original_text: 国被伸或作神创， 浸大日伸。 其发则战。 其创之发则战。 战则是使元元之民往死。 邪臣之失蓟音策也，过生於上，罪死於下。 俨既外结，诸侯畜其罪，则或作责危覆社稷，世主慑惧，寒心孤立。 不伐伐或作代，下有威字。 此人，二国之难不解，君立不复。 悔曩或作晨邮过，谋徙计易。 滥一作监首不足，盖以累重； 滥为谋首，其过重矣。 而一人之手岂足以障天下之目哉。 灭门残族#33， 灭门，周官所谓屋诛。 公谢天下，以让敌国。 不然，则战道不 绝，国创不息。 谓之伸创，以此故也。 大或作天乎哉，夫弗知之害。 以言弗知之害大矣。 悲乎哉，其祸之所极。 以言其祸可悲也已。 此倚贵离道，少人自有之咎也。 多己少人。 是故师未发轫而兵可迭也。 《近迭》名篇，盖取诸此。 今大国之君，不闻一作问先圣之道而易事，旱臣无明佐之大数，而有滑正之碎或无碎字智，反义而行之，逆德以将之，兵讪而辞穷，令不行，禁不止，又奚足怪或作恃哉。 庞子曰：何若滑正之智？ 鹖冠子曰：法度无以噫一本作遂意为摸。 噫，读为噫彼小星之噫。 圣人按数循法，尚有不全。 是故人不百其法者，不能为天下主。 今无数而自因，无法而自备，循无上圣之或作圣人检而断於己明， 断以独见之明。 人事虽备，将尚何以复百己之身乎。 夫百己者，岂独彼有之。 盖人受天地之中以生形体保神，而众妙悉备。 据今言之，其身盖有千百於己者，然而所知才止一二，而卒於泯没无问者，不能复之而已。 主知不明，以贵或作责为道，以意为法，牵或作牢，或作罕。 时诳一作诅，或作拒。 世，迢下蔽上，使事两乖， 两失之矣。
chunks.translated_text:
The state **suffers from grievances (被伸)**, or **is struck by divine punishment (作神创)**,
as **wrongs grow ever larger (浸大日伸)**.
When they **burst forth (其发)**, there is **war (则战)**.
When **grievances erupt into war (其创之发则战)**,
war **brings the common people to their deaths (则是使元元之民往死)**.

The **mistakes of evil ministers (邪臣之失)**—
**blame arises from above (蓟音策也，过生於上)**,
**punishment descends from below (罪死於下)**—
**once they are exposed (俨既外结)**,
the **feudal lords accumulate their crimes (诸侯畜其罪)**,
then **they may be accused of endangering the state (或作责危覆社稷)**,
causing the **rulers of the age to tremble in fear (世主慑惧)**,
**isolating them in cold dread (寒心孤立)**.

If they **are not punished (不伐)**,
though **they may be replaced (伐或作代)**,
**there is still the threat below (下有威字)**.
Such a man **becomes a source of perpetual conflict between two states (二国之难不解)**,
and the **sovereign’s authority is lost (君立不复)**.

**Regret comes too late (悔曩或作晨邮过)**,
**plans shift and change (谋徙计易)**.
Even **a single error (滥一作监首)** is **not enough to bear (不足)**—
**yet it is piled upon him (盖以累重)**;
**if he is the mastermind (滥为谋首)**, his **faults are grave indeed (其过重矣)**.
**How can one man’s hands block the world’s eyes (而一人之手岂足以障天下之目哉)**?

**Extinction of his clan and ruin of his kin (灭门残族#33)**—
**this is the house punishment (灭门，周官所谓屋诛)**.
**The sovereign apologizes to all (公谢天下)**,
**to atone to enemy states (以让敌国)**.
If not,
then **the Dao of war (战道)** will **never cease (不绝)**,
and **the state’s wounds will never heal (国创不息)**.
**This is called “exhausting grievances” (谓之伸创)**—
**for such is their fate (以此故也)**.

**Ah, the great harm of ignorance (大或作天乎哉，夫弗知之害)**!
**For the harm of not knowing is vast indeed (以言弗知之害大矣)**.
**Alas, the extremity of their calamity (悲乎哉，其祸之所极)**!
**For their misfortune is truly sorrowful (以言其祸可悲也已)**.
**This is leaning on nobility while abandoning the Dao (此倚贵离道)**,
**a fate of few men and many faults (少人自有之咎也)**—
**excessive self-reliance, neglect of others (多己少人)**.
**Thus, before the army even advances (师未发轫)**, its **defeat is already foreseen (而兵可迭也)**.
**“The Near Defeat” (《近迭》)** is a **famous chapter (名篇)**,
**taken from this very principle (盖取诸此)**.

Now, **the sovereigns of great states (今大国之君)**,
**do not heed the teachings of the ancient sages (不闻一作问先圣之道)** but **pursue their own desires (而易事)**,
**while their ministers lack wisdom (旱臣无明)** to **assist in great matters (佐之大数)**,
yet **possess cunning (滑正之碎或无碎字智)**—
**they act contrary to principle (反义而行之)**,
**govern against virtue (逆德以将之)**,
**their armies are disgraced (兵讪)**,
**their words exhausted (而辞穷)**,
**their commands ignored (令不行)**,
**their prohibitions defied (禁不止)**—
**what is there left to wonder at (又奚足怪或作恃哉)**?

**Pangzi said: What of this cunning (庞子曰：何若滑正之智)**?**
**Zhuanguanzi replied: The laws cannot be bent (鹖冠子曰：法度无以噫一本作遂意为摸)**—
**to grasp (噫，读为噫彼小星之噫)**.
**Even sages, following patterns and laws (圣人按数循法)**, still **fall short (尚有不全)**.
**Thus, he who does not master his own laws (是故人不百其法者)**,
**cannot rule the world (不能为天下主)**.

Now, **without principle (无数)** yet **self-reliant (而自因)**,
**without law (无法)** yet **self-sufficient (而自备)**,
**following no higher sage’s guidance (循无上圣之或作圣人检)**,
**but judging by his own limited understanding (而断於己明)**—
**though his affairs may seem complete (人事虽备)**,
**how can such a ruler ever perfect himself (将尚何以复百己之身乎)**?**

**For perfection is not his alone (夫百己者，岂独彼有之)**.
**Man is born between heaven and earth (盖人受天地之中以生)**,
**to nurture his form (形体)**,
**to preserve his spirit (保神)**,
**and all marvels are complete within him (而众妙悉备)**.
**Yet in truth (据今言之)**,
**his body contains myriad times more than he knows (其身盖有千百於己者)**,
**and he ends in oblivion (然而所知才止一二)**,
**for he cannot even perfect himself (而卒於泯没无问者)**—
**he cannot master it (不能复之而已)**.

**If the sovereign’s knowledge is unclear (主知不明)**,
**he takes nobility for the Dao (以贵或作责为道)**,
**and personal whim for law (以意为法)**,
**tying or restraining (牵或作牢，或作罕)**.
**The times are deceived (时诳一作诅)**—
**or perhaps rejected (或作拒)**.
**The world is misled (世)**,
**as the low obscures the high (迢下蔽上)**,
**and affairs become disjointed (使事两乖)**—
**both are lost (两失之矣)**.

chunks.original_text: 养非长失，以静为扰，以安为危，百姓家困人怨，祸孰大焉。 若此者，北走之日，军败日北。 后知命亡。 投死之地久矣，乃今知之。 庞子曰：以人事百法，奈何？ 鹖冠子曰：苍颉作法，一本法字在书字下#34。 苍颌，黄帝之史，初见乌兽褫远之逵，始造书契。 书从甲子。 日始於甲，辰始於子。 成史李官， 成史，盖以狱成告於正者。 李官，士师也。 苍颉不道。 然非苍颉，文墨不起。 苍虽造书不道士史，然而文墨之萌由是起矣。 此百法之端也。 纵法之载於图者，其於以喻心、达意、扬道之所谓，乃才或作巉居曼曼作受之十分一耳。 此言使无文墨而欲以其法尽之於图，岂能尽其意之详哉。 盖自后世观之，书以趣便，篆不如隶，隶不如草，则图之钝於应务可知矣。 故曰：弥纶天下之事、记久明远、着愍愍、传恣恣者，莫如书。 愍愍，目所不见。 恣恣，心所不了。 故知百法者，桀雄也。 若或作透隔无形、将然、未有者，知万人也。 此使德也，非特桀雄而已。 故其知与人隔此三境，而超万人之上也。 将然不如无形，无形不如未有。 取譬言之，若太易者，未有也； 而太初，无形； 浑沦，则将然矣。 无万人之智者，智不能栖世学之上。 庞子曰：得奉严教，受业有问或作闻矣。 退师谋言，弟子愈恐。 鹖冠子卷上竟 #1『鈇』，《四库》本言：『一作铁，非』。 #2『势』，《道藏》本原作『执』即古『势』字。 今从《四库》本作势。 按：此语出贾谊《新书·制不定》，原文为『权势法制，此人主之斤斧也』。 #3《四库》本『权」属上句而作『命权』。 #4『传』，《道藏》本原作『传』，误。 今据《四库》本改。 按：商王武丁有大臣传说，原为从事版筑业的奴东。 #5『默』，《道藏》本原作『墨』，误。 今据后文及《四库》本改。 #6《道藏》本原缺『乐嗟苦』三字。 今据《四库》本补。 #7《道藏》本原缺『人』字。 今据《四库》本补。 #8《道藏》本原缺『嗟』字。 今据《四库》本补。 #9『合』《四库》本作『矣』。 #10『元』，《四库》本作『无』。 #11《道藏》本原缺『不』字。 今据《四库》本补。 #12『尧J，《四库》本言：『一作挠』。 #13『矣』，《四库》本作『已』。 #14此句《四库》本作『以厅智为造意』。 百子本同道藏本作『为知』，今正。 #15『夸』，《四库》本作『夸』。 #16『以』，《四库》本作『已』。 #17『物』，《四库》本作『勿』。 #18『焉』，《四库》本作『马』。 #19此句《四库》本作『斯谓之调』。 #20《道藏》本原缺『微』字。 今据《四库》本补。 #21『官』，《四库》本言『一作宫』。 #22『一』《四库》本作『之』。 #23『纥』，《四库》本作『统』。 #24『或』，《道藏》本原作『成』，误。 今据文义及《四库》本改。 #25『卒』，《四库》本作『讪』。 #26『已而』，《四库》本作『而已』。 #27『其』，《四库》本作『具』。 #28『王』《四库》本作『正』。 #29『知』，《四库》本作『智』。 #30『ㄙ』，《道藏》本原作『么』，误。 《四库》本作『私』。 今据《说文》『韩非曰：苍颉作字，自营为ㄙ』句改。

「Nourishing is not a lasting loss. To take stillness as disturbance, to regard ease as peril—
the common folk suffer hardship, and people grieve.
What calamity could be greater than this?

If one acts thus, on the day he flees north,
his army will be defeated that very day.
When he realizes his fate is lost,
he will have already cast himself into the land of death long ago.

Pangzi said: *"How can one govern with myriad laws?"*
The **Huguanzi** replied: *"Cangjie created the laws.
The original form of the character *fǎ* (法) was written beneath *shū* (书).
Cangjie, the scribe of the Yellow Emperor,
first observed the tracks of birds and beasts receding into the distance,
and thus invented writing and contracts.
Writing begins with *jiǎzǐ* (甲子).
The sun begins at *jiǎ* (甲),
and the earthly branches at *zǐ* (子).
Established scribes, the **Liguan** (李官),
—*chéngshǐ* (成史), meaning those who completed and reported cases to the ruler,
and *Liguan* (李官), meaning the judicial officers—
did not follow the Dao.
Yet without Cangjie, there would be no rise of script and ink.
Though Cangjie invented writing without teaching the scribes and judicial officers,
script and ink began to sprout from this moment.
This is the origin of myriad laws.

Even if the laws are recorded in diagrams,
their purpose—illustrating the heart,
expressing intentions,
and promoting the Dao—
is but a fraction, perhaps one-tenth,
of what they truly contain.
How could one without script and ink
ever fully exhaust their intentions in diagrams?

From the perspective of later ages,
writing is for practical convenience,
seals are inferior to cursive script,
and cursive script is inferior to草书 (*cǎoshū*).
Thus, the bluntness of diagrams in responding to affairs is evident.

Therefore it is said:
*"To weave together the affairs of the world,
to record what endures and lasts far into the future,
to depict what is unseen by the eye,
and to transmit what the heart cannot comprehend—
nothing surpasses writing."*

*"Unseen by the eye"* refers to what is subtle and barely perceptible,
*"uncomprehended by the heart"* refers to what is profound and elusive.
Thus, those who know myriad laws
are the **Jiexiong** (桀雄) [tyrants and heroes].
If one understands them as *"transcending form, the unseen, and the yet-to-be"*—
then he knows the will of ten thousand people.
This is the power of virtue (*dé*), not merely the knowledge of tyrants and heroes.
Thus, his understanding surpasses that of ten thousand people,
for it spans these three realms beyond ordinary perception.

*"The yet-to-be"* is superior to *"the unseen"* (*wúxíng*),
and *"the unseen"* is superior to *"the formless"* (*húnlún*).
In analogy, if one speaks of the **Taiji** (太易),
it is *"the yet-to-be"*;
while *"the Taichu"* (太初),
is the formless;
*"the Húnlún"* (浑沦),
is the yet-to-be in its primal state.

One without the wisdom of ten thousand people
cannot dwell above the teachings of the world.
Pangzi said: *"I have received strict instruction,
and studied my craft with questions and answers."*
Yet when he consulted his teacher,
his disciples grew ever more fearful.

chunks.original_text: #31『离流』，《四库》本作『流离』。 #32『为』，《四库》本作『焉』。 #33『残族』《四库》本作『残疾族』。 #34《道藏》本此句原在『庞子曰：以人事百法，』下，误。 今据文义及《四库》本改。 鹖冠子卷中 陆佃解 度万第八 庞子问鹖冠子曰：圣与神谋， 子曰：道不同，不相为谋。 道与人成。 子曰：苟非其人，道不虚行。 愿闻度神虑成之要，奈何？ 鹖冠子曰：天者，神也。 地者，形也。 地湿而火生焉， 至阳赫赫，赫赫出乎地。 天燥而水生焉。 至阴肃肃，肃肃出乎天。 法猛刑颇则神湿， 刑与法，阴也。 神湿则天不生水。 音□#1声倒则形燥， 声与音，阳也。 形燥则地不生火。 水火不生，则阴阳无以成气，度量无以成制，五胜无以成埶一作执。 五胜，五行之胜 万物无以成类，百业俱绝，万生皆困。 济济混混，孰知其故？ 天人同文，地人同理， 天文地理，与人同焉。 贤不肖殊能，故上圣不可乱也， 譬如尧、舜，共工、欢兜欲与为恶则诛之类。 下愚不可辩也。 譬如桀、纣，龙逢、比干欲与为善则诛之类。 阴阳者，气之正也。 天地者，形神一无神字之正也。 圣人者，德之正也。 法令者，四时之正也。 季春行冬令则寒，季秋行夏令则暖。 故一义失此，万或乱彼，所失甚少，所败甚众。 所谓天者，非是苍苍之气之谓天也； 所谓地者，非是膊膊之土之谓地也。 膊，形埒也。 所谓天者，言其然物而无胜者也。 言天者，君道也，可天下之物而莫之胜也。 所谓地者，言其均物而不可乱者也。 言地者，臣道也，平天下之物而莫之乱也。 音者，其谋也。 杂比为谋。 声者，其事也。 布散为事。 音者，天之三光也。 三光杂比於上。 声者，地之五官也。 五官布散於下。 形神调则生理修， 形不病燥#2，神不病湿，则生理修矣。 夫生生而倍其本则德或作隐专已。 夫偏养其本至於过理，而不及会通之，适则自为太多，其德失乎物矣，岂足语卫生之经哉。 故曰：善养生者，若牧羊然，倪其后者而鞭之#3。 □一本元缺，一本字或作□，□知或作□如#4。 知无道，上乱天文，下灭地理， 天人同文，地人同理，於此见矣。 中绝人和，治渐终始。 言其治才渐首末，而已失中道也。 故听而无闻，视而无见， 天下之事壤於冥冥。 白昼而暗， 日中见斗之义。 有义而失谧， 人之所有，不能谥之。 失谥而惑。 责人所无，必人所不及， 远其进而诛不至也。 相史於既而不尽其爱， 史，使也。 从省。 言不尽己之爱而责人之尽。 相区於成而不索或作营其实。 区，驱也。 从省。 言不竭己之忠而望人之成。 虚名相高，精白为黑， 沽於虚名而变乱事实。 黑，或为墨。 墨亦黑也。 《诗》曰：狐狸而苍，墨以为明。 动静纽#5转， 与物转旋，如纽使之。 神绝复逆， 复有报乎上也，逆有言乎上也，言其神色距人於千里之外。 经气不类，形离正名， 《书》曰：有形有名。 形也者，物此者也。 名也者，命此者也。 经气失常，故形不丽名。 五气失端，四时不成。 阴阳并毗，四时不至，寒暑之和不成。 过生於上，罪死於下，有世将极。 驱驰索祸， 其於祸也，驱车就之。 开门逃福， 其於福也，若开门避之。 贤良为笑。 愚者为国，天咎先见，菑或作蔷，亦或作蔷。

**Lǔ Diàn’s Commentary on *Húguānzǐ* (卷中) – Chapter 8: *Dùwàn* (度万)**
**Pángzǐ asks Húguānzǐ:**
*"The Sage and the Divine deliberate together—
how does one respond?"*

**Húguānzǐ replies:**
*"The Dao differs; they do not deliberate together.
The Dao fulfills itself with humanity."*

**Pángzǐ asks:**
*"If not the proper person, the Dao does not act in vain.
I wish to hear the essentials of measuring the Divine’s deliberation and fulfilling its purpose—how so?"*

**Húguānzǐ says:**
*"Heaven is the Divine; Earth is form.
When Earth is damp, fire arises—
the utmost Yang blazes forth, blazing from the Earth.
When Heaven is dry, water arises—
the utmost Yin solemnizes, solemnizing from Heaven.

When laws are fierce and punishments excessive, the Divine grows damp—
laws and punishments are Yin.
If the Divine grows damp, Heaven does not generate water.

When sounds and tones are inverted, form grows dry—
sounds and tones are Yang.
If form grows dry, Earth does not generate fire.

If water and fire do not arise,
Yin and Yang lack the means to form *qi*,
measurements lack the means to establish order,
the Five Phases lack the means to wield their dominion.
All things lack the means to manifest their kind,
a hundred undertakings perish, ten thousand beings suffer.

Teeming and chaotic—who comprehends their cause?
Heaven and humanity share the same principles;
Earth and humanity share the same order.
Heaven’s patterns and Earth’s arrangements align with humanity.

The worthy and unworthy differ in ability—
thus, the Sage cannot be disordered,
as when Yáo and Shùn slew those who sought evil—
like Gōnggōng and Huàndōu—
nor can the foolish be discerned,
as when Jié and Zhòu slew those who sought good—
like Lóngróng and Bǐgān.

Yin and Yang are the rectitude of *qi*.
Heaven and Earth are the rectitude of form and spirit.
The Sage is the rectitude of *virtue*.
Laws are the rectitude of the four seasons.
If late spring enforces winter’s decrees, cold prevails;
if late autumn enforces summer’s decrees, warmth prevails.

Thus, one principle lost here disrupts ten thousand there—
the loss is slight, yet the ruin is vast.

What is called Heaven is not the vast *qi* of the sky;
what is called Earth is not the bare soil beneath.
*Bó* (膊) means ‘boundary of form.’

What is called Heaven speaks of that which governs all things without being overcome—
Heaven is the Way of the Sovereign,
over whom nothing under Heaven prevails.
What is called Earth speaks of that which balances all things without disorder—
Earth is the Way of the Minister,
leveling all things under Heaven without chaos.

Sound is its deliberation—
harmonized comparisons form deliberation.
Tone is its action—
dispersed implementation forms action.
Sound is Heaven’s three luminaries—
the three luminaries harmonized above.
Tone is Earth’s five senses—
the five senses dispersed below.

When form and spirit align, life’s principles are refined—
if form does not suffer from excessive dryness,
if spirit does not suffer from excessive dampness,
then life’s principles are refined.

To nurture life excessively beyond its root is to lose *virtue*—
if one over-nourishes its root beyond reason,
without attaining comprehensive harmony,
what is moderate becomes too much,
and its *virtue* fails in response to things—
how could it speak to the *Classics* of nurturing life?

Thus it is said:
*A master of nurturing life, like tending sheep,
goes behind the stragglers and urges them on.*

[Missing character]—
One version omits a character; another reads [missing character], or [missing character] as *rú* (*如*).

*"Knowledge without the Dao*
*disrupts Heaven’s patterns above,*
*erases Earth’s arrangements below.*
*Heaven and humanity share principles,*
*Earth and humanity share order—*
*this is now evident.*

*Severing harmony within humanity,*
*governance falters from beginning to end.*
*It speaks of governance that progresses from first to last*
*yet loses the central path.*

Thus, hearing without perception,
seeing without vision—
*all things under Heaven sink into obscurity.*
*Bright daylight grows dark,*
*as when the Dipper appears at noon.*

*There is principle yet no clarity—*
*what humanity possesses,*
*it cannot eulogize.*
*Losing the eulogy, it is confused.*
*Blaming what others lack,*
*it must exceed what others cannot reach—*
*driving progress far away and punishing what is unreachable.*

*Examining officials after their deeds yet failing to exhaust their love—*
*‘Shǐ’ (史) means ‘envoy.’*
*From ‘shěng’ (省).*
*It speaks of not exhausting one’s own love yet demanding others’ exhaustion.*

*Driving the people to completion yet not seeking their substance—*
*‘Qū’ (区) means ‘to drive.’*
*From ‘shěng’ (省).*
*It speaks of not exhausting one’s own loyalty yet expecting others’ achievement.*

*Empty reputations vie in height,*
*pure clarity turns to darkness.*
*Seeking hollow fame while distorting reality.*
*‘Black’ may also be ‘mò’ (墨).*
*Mò is also black.*
*The *Shījīng* says:*
*‘The fox’s pelt is gray,*
*yet black is made bright.’*

*Motion and stillness pivot like a knot—*
*adapting to things as a knot is turned.*
*The spirit severed, defiance arises—*
*defiance reports upward,*
*insubordination speaks upward,*
*speaking of the spirit’s countenance repelling others a thousand *lǐ* away.*

*The *jing* of *qi* is unnatural,*
*form departs from proper naming.*
*The *Shūjīng* says:*
*‘There is form and there is name.’*
*Form is what designates this thing.*
*Name is what commands this thing.*
*If the *jing* of *qi* strays,*
*then form does not adorn name.*

*The Five *qi* lose their proper order,*
*the four seasons fail to manifest.*
*Yin and Yang clash,*
*the four seasons do not arrive,*
*the harmony of cold and heat fails to form.*
*Excess arises above,*
*guilt brings death below—*
*the age is nearing its end.*

*They drive toward calamity,*
*as if urging a chariot toward it.*
*They open gates to flee fortune,*
*as if fleeing fortune like one fleeing through an open door.*
*The worthy are mocked.*
*The foolish govern the state,*
*Heaven’s retribution is foreseen,*
*disaster—*
*or ‘qǐ’ (蔷), also ‘qiáng’ (蔷).*

chunks.original_text: 害并杂，人执兆生#6，孰知其极。 见形而已，昧於在理。 见日月者不为明，闻雷霆者不为聪，事至而议或作义者不能使变无生。 不能消之於未萌。 故善度变者观本，本足则尽，不足则德必薄、兵必老，其执能以褊材为褒德或作襄隐博义者哉#7。 其文巧武果而奸不止者，生於本不足也。 言非少文不武之罪。 故主有二政，臣有二制，臣弗用，主不能使，臣必死，主弗能止。 是以圣王独见，故立官以授长者在内#8，和者在外。 夫长者之为官也，在内则正义，在外则固守，用法则平治#9。 人本无害，以端天地，令出一或无一字原。 多门杜矣。 散无方、化万物万物，一本#10作无物者，令也。 守一道、制万物者，法也。 法也者，守内者也。 法者，守於分域之内。 令也者，出制者也。 令者，所以行法。 夫法不败是， 是出於义变而不可常法者，所以趣变。 令不伤理， 王#11出於理一而不可变令者，所以守法。 故君子得而尊，小人得而谨，胥或作昌靡得以全。 神备於心，道备於形， 备天地之羡，称神明之容。 人以成则， 以成法则。 士或作土以为绳。 以为绳墨。 列或作削时第气，以授当名，故法错而阴阳调。 凤凰者，鹑火之禽、或无鹑火之禽，玄枵之兽字。 阳之精也。 雄曰凤，凰者其雌也。 鹑火，南星之次也。 麒麟者，玄枵之兽，阴之精也。 牝曰麟，骐者其牡也。 玄枵，北星之次也。 骐似麟而无角。 万民者，德之精也，德能致之，或作骏。 其或无其字精毕至。 庞子曰：致之奈何？
chunks.translated_text:
「Harm and disorder intermingle,
Humans grasp at omens as calamities arise—
Who can truly know their limits?

They see only form,
Yet remain blind to its underlying *Dao/Way*.
They behold the sun and moon yet do not gain true clarity,
They hear thunder yet do not become truly wise.
When matters arise, those who debate *dharma/virtue* (or *yì* 義) cannot alter fate’s inevitability.
They cannot extinguish it before its sprouting.

Thus, those who skillfully navigate change observe its roots:
If the roots are strong, all will be fulfilled;
If weak, then *virtue/power* (德) must be thin,
And soldiers must grow weary.
How can they wield *biǎn* (褊, narrow-minded) materials
To praise *shāng yǐn* (襄隐, concealing virtues) or broaden *dharma/virtue* (博义)?

Those whose words are smooth yet their actions yield no fruit,
Whose deceit does not cease—
They arise from roots that are insufficient.
It is not a fault of few words or lack of martial prowess.
Hence, rulers have two *zhèng* (政, governance),
And ministers have two *zhì* (制, measures).
If ministers do not apply them,
The ruler cannot enforce them,
Ministers must perish,
And the ruler cannot halt it.
Therefore, the sage-king perceives alone,
And establishes officials to entrust *cháng* (长, longevity/authority) to those within,
And *hé* (和, harmony) to those without.
When officials wield *cháng* (长, longevity/authority),
Within, they uphold justice;
Without, they defend the borders,
And enforce laws to maintain order.

Humans are inherently without harm,
By aligning with the proper order of Heaven and Earth,
Commands flow from singularity—
Many gates are sealed.
Dispersed without direction,
Transforming all things—
All things (or *wúwù* 无物, nothingness) arise from *order* (令).
Guarding the singular *Dao/Way*,
Regulating all things—
This is *law* (法).
*Law* (法) is the guardian within boundaries.
*Order* (令) is the one who issues regulations.
*Order* (令) is what implements *law* (法).

If *law* (法) does not fail in its principles,
These principles arise from *dharma/virtue* (義) that cannot be fixed,
And thus they pursue change.
If *order* (令) does not harm *principle/rightness* (理),
The king issues it from singular *principle* (理一),
And it cannot be altered—
This is what upholds *law* (法).
Hence, the virtuous obtain *respect* (尊),
The petty obtain *caution* (谨),
And all are preserved—
*Cháng* (昌, flourishing) or *mǐ* (靡, decline).

The mind is complete in its *divine* (神) essence,
The form is complete in its *Dao/Way* (道).
It fulfills the virtues of Heaven and Earth,
And embodies the *divine* (神明) countenance.

Humans rely on established *principles* (则),
And on established *law* (法).
The scholar uses them as his measure.
*Law* (法) is adjusted while *Yin* and *Yang* are harmonized.

The *fènghuáng* (凤凰, phoenix) is the bird of *zhēnhuǒ* (鹑火, or *wúzhēnhuǒ* 无鹑火, perhaps no bird),
The *xiāngxiū* (玄枵, dark void) beast—
The essence of *Yang*.
The male is called *fèng* (凤),
And *huáng* (凰) is its female counterpart.
*Zhēnhuǒ* (鹑火) is the second star of *Nánxīng* (南星, Southern Dipper).
The *qílín* (麒麟, kirin) is the *xiāngxiū* (玄枵) beast,
The essence of *Yin*.
The female is called *lín* (麟),
And *qí* (骐) is its male counterpart.
*Xiāngxiū* (玄枵) is the second star of *Běixīng* (北星, Northern Dipper).
*Qí* (骐) resembles *lín* (麟) yet lacks horns.

The *wànmín* (万民, ten thousand people) are the essence of *virtue/power* (德),
For *virtue/power* (德) can gather them—
Or *jùn* (骏, swift/strong).
When their essence fully arrives,
Pangzi asks:
*How does one gather them?*

chunks.original_text: 鹖冠子曰：天地阴阳，取稽於身，故布五正，以司五明#12。 五正见下。 五明宜谓名尸气皇、名尸神明、名尸贤圣、名尸后王#13、名尸公伯。 十变九道， 未详闻也。 稽从身始。 五音六律，稽从身出。 大禹以声为律，以身为度，所谓取稽於身者耶？ 五五二十五，以理天下。 五五，五其音之五也。 六六三十六，以为岁式。 六六，六其律之六也。 一岁之式，称旬三十有六。 气由神生，道由神成。 蜕气之谓虚，蜕虚之谓道。 而神也者，有而非气也，无而非道也。 非气而气以之生，非道而道以之成。 唯圣人能正其音、调其声，故其德上及#14太清， 太清，天也。 下及泰宁， 泰宁，地也。 中及万灵。 膏露降，白丹发，醴泉出， 醴泉，其味如醴，可以养老。 朱草生， 朱草，可以染终，以别尊卑。 众祥具。 《传》曰：王者统和阴阳，休气充塞，符瑞并臻，应德而至。 德至天则斗极明、日月光、甘露降，德至地则嘉禾生、蓂荚起、秬鬯出，德至文表则景星见、五纬顺轨，德至草木则朱草生、木连理，德至鸟兽则凤凰翔、鸾乌舞、骐麟臻、白虎到、白雉降、白鹿见、白乌下，德至山陵则景云出、芝实茂、陵出异丹、阜出萐莆、山出器车、泽出神鼎，德至渊泉则黄龙见、醴泉涌、河出龙图、洛出龟书、江出大贝、海出明珠，德至八方则祥风至、嘉气时、锺律调、音度施、四夷化、越裳贡。 故万口云或作去帝制神化， 众祥备至，则外帝内神之道具矣。 景星光润。 景星者，德星也。 其状无常，常出於有道之国，而月死则见，所以助月照民夜绩也。 文则寝天下之兵，武则天下之兵莫能当。 一本云：武则天下莫能当。 无之兵字。 远乎近#15，显乎隐，大乎小，众乎少，莫不从微始。 故得之所成，不可胜形； 失之所败，不可胜名。 或作胜为名。 从是往或作生者，子弗能胜问，吾亦弗胜言。 凡问之要，欲近知而远见，以一度万也。 无欲之君，不可与举。 此言何谓也？ 若予所学，则人君之患正在多欲。 此孟子三见齐王而不言，曰：我先攻其邪心也。 故曰：内实多欲而外施仁义，奈何欲效唐虞之治乎。 《南华》曰：欲顺则平气，欲神则静心，欲当则缘於不得已。 亦与《鹖冠》异矣。 昔有鬼谷着书，以为驰说诸侯，阳开阴闭，必因其好恶忧乐而裨阖之。 然至於无好者，盖不得而说也。 若然，多欲之君乃从横之家欲以售术。 而《鹖冠》言道，末流乃至於此，不已卑乎。 贤人不用，弗能使国利，此其要也。 庞子曰：敢问五正？ 鹖冠子曰：有神化，有官治，有教治，有因治，有事或作争治。 庞子曰：愿闻其形。 鹖冠子曰：神化者於未有，官治者道於本，教治者修诸己，因治者不变俗，事治者矫或作□之於末。 庞子曰：愿闻其事。 鹖冠子曰：神化者，定天地，豫或作象四时， 其体常如此。 拔或作教阴阳，移寒暑。 其体变如此。 《传》曰：古之真人，提#16挈天地，把握阴阳。 正流并生，万物无害，万类成或作咸全，名尸气皇。 伏义氏得之，以袭气母。 盖近是乎？ 官治者，师阴阳， 阴阳，王事之本。 应将然， 神化者於未有，故升此一等。 地宁天澄，众美归焉，名尸神明。 教治者，置或作署四时， 春诵、夏弦、秋学礼、冬读书之类，因时顺气，於功易也。

The **Huluguanzi** says:

The **Heaven and Earth**, *Yin* and *Yang*, take their measure from the body,
Thus the **Five Rectitudes** are arranged to govern the **Five Clarities**#12.
The **Five Rectitudes** are explained below.
The **Five Clarities** should be understood as:
*Clarity of the Vital Essence* (名尸气皇),
*Clarity of the Divine Mind* (名尸神明),
*Clarity of the Virtuous Sage* (名尸贤圣),
*Clarity of the Sovereign Ruler* (名尸后王),
*Clarity of the Noble Minister* (名尸公伯).
The **Ten Transformations** and **Nine Ways**—
Their details I have not yet heard.
The measure begins with the body.
The **Five Tones** and **Six Pitches** take their origin from the body.
Great **Yǔ** established **sound** as the **pitches** and the **body** as the **measure**—
This is what is meant by *"taking measure from the body."*
**Five times five** makes **twenty-five**, by which the world is governed.
**Five** refers to the **Five Tones**.
**Six times six** makes **thirty-six**, by which the **yearly pattern** is established.
**Six** refers to the **Six Pitches**.
The **pattern of a year** corresponds to **thirty-six decads**.
*Qi* is generated by the **Spirit**,
The **Way** is completed by the **Spirit**.
To **shed** *qi* is called **emptiness**,
To **shed** emptiness is called the **Way**.
Yet the **Spirit**—
It exists yet is not *qi*,
It does not exist yet is not the **Way**.
Though not *qi*, it gives rise to *qi*,
Though not the **Way**, it completes the **Way**.
Only the **Sage** can rectify the **tones** and harmonize the **sounds**,
Thus his **virtue/power** ascends to **Tàiqīng**—
**Tàiqīng**, the Heaven—
Descends to **Tàiníng**—
**Tàiníng**, the Earth—
And permeates all **ten thousand beings**.
Glistening dew descends,
White **elixir** emerges,
**Liquor-spring** flows,
**Liquor-spring**, its taste like *lì* (fermented rice wine), can nourish the aged.
**Crimson grass** grows,
**Crimson grass**, which can dye for rank distinction.
All auspicious signs are complete.
The *Transmission* says:
The **Sovereign** unifies *Yin* and *Yang*,
The **auspicious *qi*** fills the world,
The **auspicious signs** all arrive,
Responding to **virtue/power** and appearing.
When **virtue/power** reaches Heaven, the **Polaris** shines bright, the sun and moon radiate light, and sweet dew descends.
When **virtue/power** reaches Earth, fine millet grows, *bìngjiá* (a type of bean) sprouts, and *jùshāng* (a sacred wine) emerges.
When **virtue/power** manifests in culture, the **august star** appears, and the **Five Celestial Stems** move in harmony.
When **virtue/power** reaches plants, **crimson grass** grows, and trees bear connected branches.
When **virtue/power** reaches birds and beasts, the **phoenix** soars, the **luán** (mythical bird) dances, the **qílín** arrives, the **white tiger** appears, the **white pheasant** descends, the **white deer** is seen, and the **white crow** alights.
When **virtue/power** reaches mountains and hills, **august clouds** emerge, **lingzhi** mushrooms flourish, hills yield strange **elixir**, mounds produce *yúfú* (a medicinal herb), mountains bear chariots and vehicles, and marshes yield divine tripods.
When **virtue/power** reaches deep waters and springs, the **yellow dragon** appears, the **liquor-spring** surges, the **Yellow River** reveals dragon scriptures, the **Luo River** presents turtle books, the **Jiang River** yields great shells, and the **sea** produces bright pearls.
When **virtue/power** reaches the **eight directions**, the **auspicious wind** arrives, the **auspicious *qi*** is timely, the **bells and drums** are attuned, the **musical measures** are applied, the **four barbarians** are civilized, and the **Yùzhōu** (southern peoples) offer tribute.
Thus, when all auspicious signs are complete,
The **Way of the Outer Sovereign and Inner Spirit** is fully realized.
The **august star** shines luminous.
The **august star** is the **star of virtue/power**.
Its form is not constant,
Yet it always appears in lands of the **Dao**,
And when the month dies, it appears to assist the moon in illuminating the people’s nightly labors.
In times of **culture**, it causes the world’s armies to rest;
In times of **martial might**, no army in the world can resist it.
One version reads: *"In times of martial might, none in the world can resist."*
Without the word *"armies"*.
Far becomes near,
Hidden becomes manifest,
Great becomes small,
Many become few—
None do not begin from the subtle.
Thus what is **obtained** in its completion cannot be fully described;
What is **lost** in its defeat cannot be fully named.
One version reads: *"cannot be fully named"* instead of *"described."*
From this onward—or one version reads *"From life onward"*—
Your son cannot answer,
Nor can I speak of it.
The essentials of inquiry:
To know the near and foresee the far,
To govern the **One** and transform the **Ten Thousand**.
A ruler without desire cannot be spoken to of governance.
What does this mean?
According to my learning,
The ruler’s affliction lies in excessive desire.
This is why **Mencius**, though he saw the **King of Qi** three times, spoke not,
Saying: *"I first attack his perverse heart."*
Thus it is said:
*"Within, he is filled with excessive desire,
Yet outwardly, he practices benevolence and righteousness—
How can he hope to emulate the governance of **Tang** and **Yú**?"*
The *Nánhuá* (Southern Flower) says:
*"If desire follows harmony, the *qi* becomes even,
If desire seeks the Spirit, the mind becomes still,
If desire strives for correctness, it follows necessity."*
This differs from the *Huluguanzi*.
In ancient times, **Guǐgǔ** wrote a book
To persuade the **Marquis** through eloquence,
Using **open** and **closed** tactics,
Necessarily aligning with their likes and dislikes, joys and sorrows, to **open or close** accordingly.
Yet when one reaches the **desireless**,
One cannot persuade them.
If so, a ruler with excessive desire becomes the **Horizontalist’s** target,
Seeking to sell their schemes.
But the *Huluguanzi* speaks of the **Way**,
Yet its later currents descend to this—
Is it not too base?
If the **virtuous** are not employed,
The state cannot be made prosperous—
This is its essential point.

**Pángzǐ** asked: *"May I ask about the **Five Rectitudes**?"*
The **Huluguanzi** replied: *"There is **Spirit-transformation**, **Official governance**, **Teaching governance**, **Adaptive governance**, and **Action-governance**—or one version reads **‘Contention-governance’**."*

**Pángzǐ** asked: *"I wish to hear their forms."*
The **Huluguanzi** replied: *"**Spirit-transformation** acts before creation,
**Official governance** follows the **root**,
**Teaching governance** cultivates within oneself,
**Adaptive governance** does not alter customs,
**Action-governance** corrects—or one version reads **‘rectifies’**—at the end."*

**Pángzǐ** asked: *"I wish to hear their practices."*
The **Huluguanzi** replied: *"**Spirit-transformation**—
It stabilizes Heaven and Earth,
**Prefigures** the **Four Seasons**,
Its **essence** is always thus.
It **extracts**—or one version reads **‘teaches’**—*Yin* and *Yang*,
It **transfers** cold and heat.
Its **essence** changes thus.
The *Transmission* says:
The **True Person** of antiquity
**Lifted** Heaven and Earth,
**Grasped** *Yin* and *Yang*.
The **flow** was rectified, and all things were born without harm,
All classes were fully realized—
This is called **Clarity of the Vital Essence**.
**Fúyì** obtained it,
To inherit the **Essence-Mother**.
Is this not close?
**Official governance**—
It **models** *Yin* and *Yang*,
*Yin* and *Yang*, the **root of royal affairs**,
Responding to what should be.
**Spirit-transformation** acts before creation,
Thus it ascends to a higher rank.
Earth is tranquil, Heaven is clear,
All beauties gather—
This is called **Clarity of the Divine Mind**.
**Teaching governance**—
It **establishes** the **Four Seasons**,
Such as reciting in spring, playing strings in summer, studying rites in autumn, and reading books in winter,
Following the seasons and aligning with *qi*—
Thus its **achievements** are easy."

chunks.original_text: 事功顺道， 俯而事功，仰以顺道。 名尸贤圣。 因治者，招或作拓贤圣而道心术，敬事生和，名尸后王。 事治者，招仁圣而道知焉， 不能招贤圣而招仁，不能道心术而道知。 圣也者，天道也。 贤也者，地道也。 仁也者，人道也。 苟精牧神， 苟，急敕也。 牧，驱制也。 分官成章， 精神劳矣，而不能普遍#17，於是又备官焉。 教苦利远， 教虽苦而利远。 法制生焉。 万法扰扰，自此起矣。 法者，使去私就公， 法者，将以有所去也，非以有所取也。 同知壹警，有同由者也，非行私而使人合同者也。 故至治者弗由，而名尸公伯。 公如公侯之公，伯如霸王之伯。 王鈇第九 庞子问鹖冠子曰：泰上成鸠一作鹖之道，一族用之万八千岁。 《传》曰：天地初立，天皇一曰天灵，其治万八千岁。 然则成鸠盖天皇之别号也。 有天下兵强，世不可夺。 天地初立，岂容已有兵哉。 此言亦筌蹄也。 《南华》曰：寓言十九，重言十七。 与天地存，久绝无伦。 无伦，细之至也。 《中庸》曰：毛犹有伦。 齐殊异之物， 齐鹏鴳之大小，等凫鹤之长短。 不足以命其相去之不同也。 言其悬绝如此。

**Translation:**

*"To govern by aligning with the Dao—
Bow low to govern, rise high to align with the Dao.
This is called **Exalted Sagehood**.

For those who rule,
They summon **Exalted Sagehood** and cultivate the **Art of the Dao-heart**,
With reverence in service, harmony in life—
This is called **Later Sovereignty**.

For those who govern,
They summon **Ren-Sainthood** and seek wisdom within,
Yet cannot summon **Exalted Sagehood** nor attain the **Art of the Dao-heart**—
Only **Ren-Sainthood** and wisdom.

**Sainthood** is the **Dao of Heaven**.
**Exalted Sagehood** is the **Dao of Earth**.
**Ren-Sainthood** is the **Dao of Man**.

If one **refines the herding of the Spirit**—
*Refinement* is urgent command,
*Herding* is driving and restraining.
Officials are appointed, their roles defined,
Yet the **Spirit-essence** grows weary,
Unable to **pervade universally**,
Thus additional officials are established.

**Teaching** is bitter yet its benefits are distant—
Though teaching is bitter, its benefits are distant.
From this arise **laws and institutions**.
The myriad laws are in tumult—
From here they arise.

**Law** is to make one abandon private gain for the public good—
**Law** is to remove, not to bestow.
**Uniform knowledge and unified warning**—
It is to have those of shared principle,
Not to force private conformity.

Thus, in the **most refined governance**, it is not so—
Yet it is called **Public Lordship**.
*Public* as in the **Public Lord**,
*Lord* as in the **Dominant Sovereign**.

**Chapter Nine: The Hammer of Kings**
Pangzi asked the **Crowned Crane Master**:
‘The **Dao of the Supreme Sage**—
When one clan upholds it, it lasts ten thousand years.
The *Transmission* says:
*"When Heaven and Earth were first established,
The **Celestial Sovereign**—also called **Heavenly Spirit**—
Ruled for ten thousand years.
Thus, the **Supreme Sage** was likely another name for the **Celestial Sovereign**.

Yet in the world, armies grew strong,
And the age could not be seized.
When Heaven and Earth were first established,
How could there already have been armies?
This is but a **fishing net and trap**—
A metaphor, not fact.’

The *Southern Bloom* says:
‘Allegory is nineteen parts,
Repeated speech is seventeen parts.
To endure with Heaven and Earth,
Long since severed from all resemblance.
*Severed*—the most refined distinction.’

The *Central Harmony* says:
‘Even hair retains its order.
To equal the disparate—
The vast difference between **Peng and Wild Goose** in size,
The varying lengths of **Teal and Crane**—
This is insufficient to describe their divergence.
Such is their utter separation.’"*

chunks.original_text: 世莫不言树俗立化，彼独何道之行以至於此？ 鹖冠子曰：彼成鸠氏天， 句。 故莫能增其高，尊其灵。 庞子曰：何谓天？ 何若而莫能增其高，尊其灵？ 凡此叩其所以。 鹖冠子曰：天者，诚其日德也。 日或无日字诚出诚入，南北有极， 冬日至而北，夏日至而南。 故莫弗以为法则。 取中於日德。 天者，信其月刑也。 月信死信生，终则有始， 朔而后魄生，望而后魄死。 故莫弗以为政。 取正於月刑。 天者，明星其稽也。 明星，大星也。 二十八舍之类。 列或作削星不乱，各以序行，故小大莫弗以章。 小星不见陵掩#18。 天者，因时其则也。 四时当名，代或作伐而不干或作于， 彼□此代而无侵越。 故莫弗以为必然。 天者，一法其或无其字同也。 前后左右，古今自如， 奈何祀人之忧其崩坠也。 故莫弗以为常。 天诚、信、明、因、一， 诚，诚其日德。 信，信其月刑。 明，明星其稽。 因，因时其则。 一，一法其同。 不为众父。 或作文。 为众父父。 易一，故莫能与争先。 《南华》曰：一而不可不易者，道也。 先，或为光。 易一非一， 一不足以囿之。 故不可尊增。 成鸠得一，故莫不仰制焉。 所谓侯王得一为天下贞者也。 庞子曰：愿闻其制。 鹖冠子曰：成鸠之制，与神明体正。 神明者，下究而上际， 况以穷乎下，浮以际乎上。 克啬万物而不可厌者也。 周怕或作汨，或作流徧照， 周泊，无外也。 徧照，无裹也。 反与天地总，故能为天下计。 往而不反#19，岂能与民同吉凶之患哉。 明於蚤识，逢臼或作远臼#20不惑，存亡之祥，安危之稽。 庞子曰：愿闻其稽。 鹖冠子曰：置下不安，

The world has none who do not speak of **cultivating customs and establishing transformations**—
yet how could he alone **practice the Dao** to reach such an extreme?

The *Lüguanzi* says:
*"He achieved the Dao of the Peng Sovereign of Heaven."* (A pause.)

Thus, none could **augment his virtue/power** or **exalt his spiritual essence**.

Pangzi said:
*"What is this Dao of Heaven?*
*How does it manifest so that none can augment his virtue/power or exalt his spiritual essence?"*
This is to **inquire into its origin**.

The *Lüguanzi* replied:
*"The Dao of Heaven is the **authenticity of the Sun’s virtue/power**.*
*The Sun either has its name or does not—*
*when the solstices come,*
*winter brings the Sun’s retreat to the north,*
*summer brings its return to the south.*
*Thus, none dare fail to follow it as a principle.*
*He takes the **centrality of the Sun’s virtue/power**.*

*The Dao of Heaven is the **trustworthiness of the Moon’s phases**.*
*The Moon trusts in death and trusts in birth,*
*ending to begin anew—*
*when the new moon arrives, the light is born,*
*when the full moon arrives, the light dies.*
*Thus, none dare fail to follow it as governance.*
*He takes **rectitude from the Moon’s phases**.*

*The Dao of Heaven is the **illumination of the stars’ alignment**.*
*The stars are the great stars—*
*those of the Twenty-Eight Constellations.*
*Though their ranks may be **eroded or arranged**,*
*they proceed in their proper order,*
*so that none can disrupt their **chaptered harmony**.*
*Small stars do not vanish when obscured.* (Missing character: *#18*)

*The Dao of Heaven is the **adherence to seasonal order**.*
*The four seasons follow their names,*
*replacing or **transforming** each other without **encroaching or clashing**.*
*Thus, none dare fail to follow it as an inevitable law.*
*He takes **timely regulation** from the seasons.*

*The Dao of Heaven is the **unity of its singular method**—*
*whether it be **manifest or latent**,*
*its **identity remains unchanged**.*
*Before and after, left and right,*
*past and present—all align naturally.*
*Yet why should people **worry over their own decline and fall**?*
*Thus, none dare fail to follow it as a constant.*
*The Dao of Heaven is **authenticity, trustworthiness, illumination, adherence, and unity**—*
*authenticity in the Sun’s virtue/power,*
*trustworthiness in the Moon’s phases,*
*illumination in the stars’ alignment,*
*adherence in seasonal order,*
*unity in its singular method.*
*It does not act as a **universal progenitor**.*
*Or it **transforms** into a universal progenitor.*
*It **transforms** into a universal progenitor.*
*Changing its unity, yet not abandoning it,*
*unity alone is insufficient to **contain** it.*
*Thus, none can exalt or augment it.*
*Peng achieved this unity,*
*so none dare fail to **submit to his governance**.*
*This is what is meant by a **sage-king who upholds the Dao** for the world.*

Pangzi said:
*"I wish to hear of his governance."*

*"A pile of earth—*
*too low to bear a load,*
*or perhaps it can,*
*but its feet are stacked precariously.*
*Yet even the highest mound cannot stand firm—*
*such is the nature of peril and safety.*
*To heap the low and seek stability above*
*is difficult indeed.*
*What then of those who stand upon it?*
*How could their footing not falter?*
*‘Stacked feet’ means to tread,*
*‘planting’ means to stand,*
*‘curved’ means to bend.*

*Discerning human nature,*
*probing the principles of all things,*
*harmonizing with Heaven and Earth—*
*‘harmonizing’ means to measure,*
*to govern without peril.*
*Surveying mountains and rivers,*
*to move and align all things with order—*
*the slow and the swift,*
*the confined and the free.*
*Nurturing life without harm,*
*parents without blame.*
*Generous in taking and giving,*
*thorough in teaching the Dao—*
*teaching for others,*
*the Dao for oneself.*
*Concise in speech,*
*‘speech’ means direct words,*
*‘language’ means questioning doubts.*
*Faithful in agreements,*
*fulfilling promises without evasion,*
*returning promises as one’s own.*
*The *Rites* say:*
*‘Better to bear resentment*
*than to break a promise.’*
*Neither joy nor anger oversteps—*
*joy does not exceed generosity,*
*anger does not exceed taking away.*
*His armies are not martial,*
*but rooted in custom,*
*and his influence stems from this.*

Pangzi said:
*'I wish to hear of human nature and the principles of things,*
*how to restrain all things,*
*harmonize with Heaven and Earth,*
*and embody the divine and upright.'*

The *Lüguanzi* replied:
*'The Way of Chengjiu*
*has never strayed from Heaven’s curves or the Sun’s methods.*
*Heaven’s curves are clear and easy to follow.*
*The Sun’s methods are essential and easy to practice.*
*Heaven’s curves are like organizing five families into a *wu* and five *wu* into a county.*
*The Sun’s methods are like using household heads for daily oversight and *dian* officials for decadal reviews.*
*This system arose in the late Zhou,*
*yet it is said Chengjiu employed it—*
*as if today’s innovations were yesterday’s truths.*
*Thus, this text contains many allegories.*

Pangzi said:
*'I wish to hear of Heaven’s curves and the Sun’s methods.'*

The *Lüguanzi* replied:
*'In governing the towns,*
*let those skilled in five families form a *wu*,*
*and its leader oversee them.*
*Ten *wu* form a *li*, and the *li* appoints officials.*
*Four *li* form a *bian*—*
*—*though *bian* should be *dian*.*
*—and its leader governs.*
*Ten *bian* form a *xiang*, and the *xiang* appoints a teacher.*
*Five *xiang* form a county, with a *shefu* to administer.*
*Ten counties form a prefecture, governed by a great official.*
*These are called ‘official attendants.’*
*The prefecture’s great official inspects his counties,*
*the *shefu* inspects his *xiang*,*
*the *xiang* teacher inspects his *bian*,*
*the *bian* leader inspects his *li*,*
*the *li* officials inspect their *wu*,*
*and the *wu* leader inspects his households.*
*Matters are mutually verified,*
*residences mutually observed,*
*comings and goings mutually supervised.*
*—*‘Supervised’ means to watch closely.*
*Fathers speak of righteousness to fathers,*
*children speak of filial piety to children.*
*Elders speak of goodness,*
*the young of respect.*
*Morning and evening, they permeate one another,*
*thus cultivating filial devotion.*

*If any move or settle,*
*households receive them,*
*people entrust one another;*
*the missing or stolen have no place to hide.*
*This is the nature of human affairs and things.*

*If a *wu* has surplus or shortage in dwellings,*
*or violates orders without cause,*
*they must report to the *li* officials—*
*yet if they fail to report,*
*it is called ‘disorder in the household,’*
*and the *wu* leader shares the blame.*
*—*‘Shares the blame’ means the *wu* leader is held accountable for the *wu*’s offense.*

*If the *li* has disrespect for elders or neglects the young,*
*or behaves differently from others,*
*and does not fully report to the *bian* leader,*
*it is called ‘disorder in the *li*,’*
*and the *li* officials are punished,*
*while the offending household is made an accessory.*
*—*‘Accessory’ means secondary.*

*If the *bian* fails to timely inspect and teach,*
*and does not fully report to the *xiang* teacher,*
*it is called ‘disorder in the *bian*,’*
*and the *bian* leader is punished,*
*while the offending household is made an accessory.*

*If the *xiang* fails to timely inspect and teach,*
*and does not fully report to the county *shefu*,*
*it is called ‘disorder in the *xiang*,’*
*and the *xiang* teacher is punished,*
*while the offending household is made an accessory.*

*If the county *shefu* fails to timely inspect and teach,*
*and does not fully report to the prefecture,*
*while good deeds go unrecognized*
*—*called ‘obscuring clarity’—*
*or evils are concealed*
*—*called ‘lowering comparisons’—*
*it is called ‘disorder in the county,’*
*and the *shefu* is executed without pardon.*
*—*It does not mention making households accessories,*
*for if the punishment reaches households,*
*execution is inevitable.*

*If the prefecture’s great official fails to inspect and teach,*
*and though aware of faults,*
*does not fully instruct the *zhuguo*,*
*it is called ‘disorder in the prefecture,’*
*and the great official is executed without pardon.*

*If the *zhuguo* governs poorly,*
*so that lower concerns do not reach above*
*and upper commands do not penetrate below,*
*it is called ‘urgent mismanagement,’*
*and the *zhuguo* is executed,*
*his clan exterminated.*

*The *Yuan* refers to *qi*,*

*the station of Earth begins with *Xuánshuò* (Dark Beginning).*
*The Four Seasons begin with the *Lì* (Calendar).*

*Thus, the Sage-King solemnly entrusts governance to the people,*
*and the true beginning of time lies in the *Lì*.*
*Hence, within the household, one uses *tí* (New Moon),*
*—the *tí* being the zero day of the month._
*The *Gōngyáng Zhuàn* (Public Sprouts Annals) states:*

The *xiàqíng* (lower officials) report upward every sixty days,

this is the *tiāncù rìshù* (Heaven’s rhythmic art of days).

Thus, the unworthy do not escape their lowliness,
while the virtuous do not lose their brilliance—
*—alternate reading: the Son of Heaven’s favors are bestowed in order,*

Those who act contrary to the Way are not rewarded!
Under Heaven’s rule, all is serene—

Thus none can thwart its strength,
and so it governs the fullness without overflowing,
*—alternate reading: it does not increase what should not be increased,*
*to cause overflowing.*

It sustains the great without diminishing—
*—alternate reading: it does not harm the great,*

chunks.original_text: 非故杀之。 人得所欲，国无变故，着赏有功，德及三世。 父或作各#24伏或作状其辜不得创谥。 名之曰幽厉，虽孝子慈孙不能改也创，或为制。 事从一二终古不勃。 彼计为善於乡不如为善於里。 为善於里，不如为善於家。 得诛。 是以为善者可得举，为恶者可得诛。 或作谕。 莫敢道一旦之善，皆以终身为期。 素无失次，故化立而世无邪。 化立俗成，少则同侪，或作齐长则同友，游敖同品，祭祀同福，死生同爱，祸灾同忧，居处同乐。 灾安居日处。 行作同和，吊贺同杂，哭泣同哀。 欢欣足以相助，□谍或作谋足以相止。 □，探道也。 谍，间谋也。 同安平相驯，军旅相保，夜战则足以相信，昼战则足以相配或作丑。 入以禁暴，出正无道，是以其兵能横行诛伐，而莫之敢御。 故其刑设而不用，不争而权重，车甲不陈而天下无敌矣。 一本作天下无道适矣。 失道则贱敢逆贵，不义则小敢侵大。 成鸠既见上世之嗣失道亡功、倍或作信本灭德之则，故为之不朽或作株，又或作采之国，定位牢或作罕祭，或作然。 不能保其邦家则位不定矣，不能保其宗庙则祭不牢矣。 使鬼神亶曰：或作日。 增规不圆，益矩不方， 此言法度至足，无欠无余，规不可增，矩不可益，非特使人信之，虽质诸鬼神而无疑也。 盖圣人之法譬诸身乎，增之则赘，割之则亏。 夫以效末传之子孙，唯此可持，或无唯此可持字。 唯此可将。 效，犹示也，读如效犬、效羊之效。 言以示子孙之末裔，立而可持，行而可将，唯此而已。 将者养吉，释或作泽者不祥，墠以全牺， 纯谓之牺，完谓之栓。 正以齐明，齐，或作天，或作文。 不草谓之齐#25，不昧谓之明。 齐明者，盖祭祀之正也； 牺牷则以为副而已。 《礼》曰：去庙为桃，去桃为坛，去坛为墠。 今此独言墠者，於墠如此，则由坛而上可知也。 四时享之，祀以家王， 子孙祭祀不辍，所谓祀以家王。 以为神享。 礼灵之符，藏之宗庙，以尔正诸或作诸侯， 为之信符，藏之宗庙，而又以其玺正之，以明后世所当守也。 故其后世之保教也全。 句。

chunks.original_text: 耳目不营，用心不分，不见异物而迁，捐或作指私去毒，或作也。 捐己之私，去人之毒。 钩此字上有每字。 一本钩作均。 於内哲，或作哲。 智足以及之。 固於所守， 仁足以守之。 更始逾新， 周而更始，久而愈新。 上元为纪，共承嘉惠，相高不改。 亶昭穆， 汤不先契，文武不先不窋，鲁跻僖公失是矣。 具或作其招士， 疑。 此先结之#26，后入弗解。 先入者定矣，故后入之事弗能解也。 此知极之至也。 极如纪极之极。 庞子曰：愿闻所以不改更始逾新之 道。 鹖冠子曰：成鸠，所谓得王鈇之传者也。 庞子曰：何谓王鈇？ 鹖冠子曰：王鈇者，非一世之器也。 以死遂生， 以杀止杀。 从中制外之教也。 教或为数。 后世或作世后成至，孙一灵羽，灵或作虚。 理或作理虚羽埋。 或作虚村理。 符日循，或作修。 功弗敢或无敢字败。 智者虽工，弗敢败也。 奉业究制，执正守内，拙弗敢废。 愚者虽拙，弗敢废也。 楼□与旱，苏本作楼剒与卑。 疑早或为早。 以新续故。

chunks.original_text: 人君爽惑不嗣，其罪如上所云，则继其后者据旧鉴新，岂敢辄异哉。 民心不徙，与天合则， 句。 万年一范， 范，如《荀子》范形之范。 则近者亲其善，远者慕其德而无已。 是以其教不厌，其用不弊，故能畴合四海以为一家，而夷貉万国皆以时朝服致绩，或作续。 而莫敢效增或作蹭兔。 此言夷貉万国皆以朝服致贡，而不敢辄增，亦不敢免。 《法言》曰：被我纯绩，带我金犀。 此之谓也。 闻者传译来归其义， 又其远者。 莫能易其俗、移其教， 《孟子》所谓：用夏变夷，未闻变於夷者也。 故其威立而不犯，流远而不废。 此素皇内帝或作端之法， 帝者，天号。 王者，人称。 皇者，天人之总，美大之名。 谓之素皇内帝，则又其至者也，盖至人神矣。 由是而在下则玄圣外王之道也，由是而在上则素皇内帝之法也。 成鸠之所枋以超等， 枋，柄也。 世世不可夺者也。 功日益月长，故能与天地存久。 此所以与神明体或作礼正之术也。 不待士史或作女苍颉作书，故后世莫能云其咎。 士，李官也。 太古无法而治，不立士史，不造书契，而至德玄同。 使由之者不能知，知之者不能名，尚何议其咎也哉。 《传》曰：苍颌作书，鬼夜哭，天雨粟。 方是之时，至德衰矣。 未闻不与道德究，究字下或有谓字。 而能以为善者也。 庞子曰：如是古今之道同邪？ 鹖冠子曰：古者亦我而使之久，众者亦我而使之众耳，何比异哉。 彼类善则万世不忘， 类，犹聚也。 道恶则祸及其身，尚或作有奚怪焉。 庞子曰：以今之事观古之道，舟车相通，衣服同采，言语相知，画地守之，不能相犯，殊君异长，不能相使，逆言过耳，兵甲相李，或作履。 李，如李官之李。 李者，治也。 百父母子，且或作其未易领#27。 或作顷。 言父母暨子至百不易领矣。 方若所言，未有离中国之正也。 离，附也。 言以上所云，方若畴合四海以为一家之言，似违中国之正远矣。 丘第之业， 第，里第也。 域或作或不出着， 着，土着也。 居不连块， 毁墙曰块。 而曰成鸠氏周阖四海为一家，夷貉夷貉，或作第却。 万国莫不来朝，其果情一本情下有可字。 一本情作成。 乎？ 此言丘里之间，其业之异如此，又况四海夷貉之远乎。 鹖冠子曰：虎或作唐狼杀或作救人，或作下。 乌苍从上，演蛾一作蝼蚁。 从下聚之。 乌，乌乌也。 苍，苍蝇也。 六者异类，然同时俱至者，何也？ 所欲同也。 由是观之，有人之名，则同人之情耳，何故不可乎？ 此言四海之情同以为一家，无不可者。 天度数之而行，在一不少，在万不众，同如林木，积如仓栗，斗石以陈，升委无失也。 委，亦米之数也。 《传》曰：少曰委，多曰积。 其数未详闻也。 《礼》云：出入三积。 列或作削地分民，亦尚一也耳，或无耳字。 百父或作交母子何能增减？ 殊君异长又 何出入？ 若能正一，万国同极，德至至下或有制字四海又奚足阖也？ 庞子曰：果必信然，阴阳消散，三百六十日各反或作及其故，天地局局或作□奚足以疑？ 局局，狭貌。 《孟子》所谓：天之高也，星辰之远也，苟求其故，千岁之日至可坐而致也。 圣人高大，内揣深浅远近之理，或作异。 使鬼神一失， 一失，失其奥也。 此言圣人烛理，有以窥之。 不复息矣。

This is why it harmonizes with the **Divine and Bright,**
*—annotation: "To align with the Divine and Bright" (神明) or "proper rituals" (礼正)*—
**without relying on scholars or scribes**
*—annotation: "Scholars" (士), ritual officials;
"Scribes" (史), record-keepers;
"Female Cangjie" (女苍颉), the mythical inventor of Chinese characters"*—
to compose writings,
so later ages cannot fault its governance.

In **Primeval Times, there was governance without laws,**
no appointment of ritual officials,
no creation of written contracts,
yet virtue and the Dao were profoundly unified.
*—annotation: "Those who followed it could not comprehend it,
and those who comprehended it could not name it—
how could they then discuss its faults?"*—

The **Transmission** says:
*"When Cangjie invented writing,*
*the spirits wept at night,*
*and Heaven rained millet."*
*—annotation: "At that time,*
*the utmost virtue had declined.*
*—annotation: "No one has ever heard of*
*not exhausting the study of virtue and the Dao,*
*yet still calling it ‘good’"*—

**Master Pang** said:
*"Is this the shared Dao/Way of past and present?"*

**Master Lùguān** said:
*"The ancients also made me endure,*
*and the multitude also made me vast—*
*what difference is there?"*
*—annotation: "If aligned with virtue,*
*it shall never be forgotten through ten thousand generations.*
*—annotation: "If aligned with the Dao/Way of evil,*
*calamity shall befall even its own lineage.*
*—annotation: "How could there be any doubt?"*—

**Master Pang** said:
*"Observing the ancient ways through modern affairs,*
*boats and carriages connect,*
*garments share colors,*
*speech is mutually understood,*
*and they mark the earth to defend it,*
*—annotation: "Yet none dare to trespass"*—
**though their rulers differ and their leaders vary,*
*—annotation: "Yet none dare to command others"*—
**and rebellious words are met with death,*
*—annotation: "Armor and weapons are worn for defense"*—
**yet even a hundred generations of parents and children**
*—annotation: "How could they increase or decrease?"*—
**cannot alter it.**
*—annotation: "How could their rulers and leaders differ?"*—

If one can **rectify the singular,**
all nations shall align at the same pole,
and the utmost virtue **shall govern the Four Seas—**
*—annotation: "What need then for unification?"*—

**Master Lùguān** said:
*"If this is indeed true,*
*—annotation: "Then when yin and yang disperse,*
*the 360 days each return to their original order,*
*—annotation: "Heaven and Earth are bound by their natural cycles—*
*how could there be any room for doubt?"*—
*—annotation: "Bound" (局局), narrow and confined"*—
*—annotation: "As the *Mencius* says:*
*‘The height of Heaven, the distance of the stars—*
*if one seeks their original order,*
*even the solstices of a thousand years can be understood while seated.’*"—

The **Sage’s** grandeur and depth
*—annotation: "Within, they grasp the profound logic of deep and shallow, far and near"*—
**pierce the mysteries of divinity and spirit,**
*—annotation: "If even one principle is lost,*
*—annotation: "Lost" (一失), to lose its essence"*—
**and there is no return to stillness.**

chunks.original_text: 运而不停。 与或作为天地相蔽， 蔽天地而不耻。 至今尚在，以钲面达行。 疑。 宜乎哉，成鸠之万八千岁也。 夫道者，天地之母，缩而修身，伸以治国，皆可以长久。 此广成子之所以千二百年，而成鸠氏之所以万八千岁也。 故曰广成子之谓天矣，又曰成鸠氏天。 故莫能增其高，尊其灵。 得此道者，何辨谁氏所用之国，而天下利耳。 用之则是，安辨孰何#28？ 泰鸿第十 泰一者， 泰一，天皇大帝也。 执大同之制，制，或作利。 泰一无所不同，故曰执大同之制。 楚人忘弓，未能忘楚； 孔子曰：惜哉，其未大也。 调泰鸿之气， 泰一，含元气者，故曰调泰鸿之气。 鸿蒙，元气也。 泰鸿，元气之始也。 正神明之位者也。 《南华》所谓：天尊地卑，神明之位。 故九皇受傅， 受教於傅。 以索其然之所生。 傅谓之得天之解，或作天然之解。 不与法缚，不求法脱。 傅谓之得天地之所始。 生天生地。 傅谓之道，得道之常。 不妄曰常。 傅谓之圣人，圣人之道，与神明相得，故曰道德。 德者，得此者也。 郄始穷初， 郄者，开也。 有初然后有始。 《列子》曰：太易者，未见气也。 太初者，气之始也。 太始者，形之始也。 太素者，质之始也。 太一至矣，其地盖处太易、太素之间，故曰郄始穷初。 得齐之所出， 帝出乎震，齐乎巽。 而太一者郄始穷初，得齐之所出，故能北辨而南，与万物相见。 九皇殊制而政莫不效焉，故曰泰一。 泰一者，无适而非一也，故九皇殊制而不能二也焉#29。 泰皇问泰一曰：天、地、人事三者，孰急？ 泰皇，盖九皇之长也。 泰一曰：爱精、养神、内端者，所以希天。 内直者，与天为徒。 天也者，神明之所根也，醇化四时，陶涎无形， 埏，和土也。 刻镂未萌， 木曰刻，金曰镂。 凡此亦皆自然也，夫岂物刻而雕之？ 离文或作父将或作特然者也。 离，华离也。 天道造始而地事终之，故其言如此。 地者，承天之演，备载以宁者也。 吾将告汝神明之极，天、地、人事三者复一也。 立置臣义， 此将从体起用，和同天人之际，使之无间，故先建立君臣之义。 所陈四则#30， 四则，即上所云傅谓之得天之解、傅谓之得天地之所始、傅谓之得道之常、傅谓之圣人。 散以八风， 东方曰明庶风，西方曰阊阖风，西南曰凉风，东北曰融风之类。 散谓散上四则，他皆放此。 揆以六合， 揆，言总之六合之内也。 事以四时，写以八极， 写，言放之八极之外也。 照以三光，牧或作收以刑德，调以五音，正以六律，分以度数，表以五色，改以二气， 亭之以温凉，毒之以寒暑。 致以南北， 南北谓日。 齐以晦望， 晦望谓月。 受以明历。 或作历。 历，谓日月星辰。 盖四则至矣，而其道无乎不在，在此为此，在彼为彼。 故八风得以散，六合得以揆，四时得以事，八极得以写，三光得以照，五音得以调，六律得以正，刑德得以牧，度数得以分，五色得以表，二气得以改，南北得以致，晦望得以齐，明历得以受。 然则，道之所在，於彼乎？ 於此乎？
chunks.translated_text:
The Dao/Way moves yet never halts.
*—annotation: "Its motion is eternal"*—
It **veils Heaven and Earth** while **not ashamed**.
*—annotation: "蔽 (veils/overshadows)"—
*—annotation: "To veil" (蔽), as if a mother enfolding her children*—
*—annotation: "不耻 (not ashamed)"—*
*—annotation: "To veil" (蔽), as if a mother enfolding her children*—
*—annotation: "至今尚在 (still persists today)"—*
*—annotation: "以钲面达行 (through the resonance of the *zhēng* bell)"*—
*—annotation: "钲 (zhēng), a ritual bell"—*
*—annotation: "达行 (reaches its course), harmonizes action"*—
**Doubt it?** It is fitting indeed—
*—annotation: "宜乎哉 (how fitting!)"*—
for the **Great Crow (Chéngjiū)** to span **eighteen thousand years**.
*—annotation: "成鸠 (Chéngjiū), a mythic figure representing primordial unity"—*
*—annotation: "万八千岁 (eighteen thousand years), an age of boundless duration"*—

The **Dao/Way**, indeed,
*—annotation: "夫 (now/indeed), a rhetorical particle emphasizing truth"*—
is the **mother of Heaven and Earth**,
*—annotation: "天地之母 (mother of Heaven and Earth), the primal source"*—
**contracting to refine the self**,
*—annotation: "缩 (contracts), draws inward"*—
**expanding to govern the realm**,
*—annotation: "伸 (extends), reaches outward"*—
**both yielding enduring virtue/power**.
*—annotation: "皆可以长久 (both can endure), their effects are lasting)"*—
This is why **Guangchéngzi** lived **a thousand two hundred years**,
*—annotation: "广成子 (Guangchéngzi), a legendary Daoist sage)"*—
and why **Great Crow (Chéngjiū)** spanned **eighteen thousand years**.
*—annotation: "故 (thus), explaining their longevity)"*—

Hence, it is said: **"Guangchéngzi is called Heaven,"**
*—annotation: "广成子之谓天 (Guangchéngzi is termed Heaven)"*—
**and again, "Great Crow is Heaven."**
*—annotation: "又曰成鸠氏天 (Great Crow is also termed Heaven)"*—
Thus, none can **exalt his grandeur**,
*—annotation: "增 (exalt), raise beyond measure"*—
**or revere his spirit**.
*—annotation: "尊 (revere), honor as divine)"*—
Those who **grasp this Dao/Way**—
*—annotation: "得此道者 (those who attain this Dao)"*—
what need is there to **distinguish whose realm they serve**,
*—annotation: "何辨 (what need to distinguish), discern differences"*—
when the **world is already benefited**?
*—annotation: "而天下利 (yet the world is benefited)"*—

**Apply it, and it is right**; how could one **distinguish who is wrong**?
*—annotation: "用之则是 (apply it, and it is correct)"*—
*—annotation: "安辨孰何 (how could one distinguish who is wrong), rhetorical inversion"*—

---

**Tàihóng the Tenth**,
*—annotation: "泰鸿 (Tàihóng), a mythic sovereign of the Three Sovereigns and Five Emperors era"*—
**Tàiyī, the Sovereign of Great Unity**,
*—annotation: "泰一 (Tàiyī), the Heavenly Sovereign, Great Emperor"*—
**holds the system of Great Harmony**,
*—annotation: "执大同之制 (adheres to the Great Harmony system)"*—
*—annotation: "制 (system), or 作利 (as profit/benefit)"*—
**Tàiyī differs from none**, hence it is called **"holding the system of Great Harmony."**
*—annotation: "无所不同 (differs from none), universal accord"*—

The **people of Chu forgot their bows**,
*—annotation: "楚人忘弓 (Chu people forgot their bows), metaphor for losing one’s native identity"*—
yet **could not forget Chu**.
*—annotation: "未能忘楚 (yet could not forget Chu), lingering attachment"*—
**Confucius said: "Alas, they have not yet attained Greatness!"**
*—annotation: "惜哉，其未大也 (alas, they have not yet attained Greatness), lamenting partial realization)"*—

**He attunes the *Tàihóng* qi**,
*—annotation: "调泰鸿之气 (attunes the *Tàihóng* qi)"*—
for **Tàiyī is the one who contains the primal qi**.
*—annotation: "含元气者 (one who contains the primal qi), the source of all"*—
*—annotation: "元气 (yuángǐ), primal qi, the undifferentiated breath of Heaven and Earth"*—
*—annotation: "泰鸿 (Tàihóng), the beginning of the primal qi"*—
**the one who rectifies the divine and luminous position**.
*—annotation: "正神明之位者 (rectifies the divine and luminous position)"*—
*—annotation: "神明 (shénmíng), divine luminosity, the radiant intelligence of the cosmos"*—

As the *Nánhuá* says:
*"Heaven is exalted, Earth is humble—*
the **divine and luminous position**."*
*—annotation: "《南华》 (Nánhuá, *Zhuangzi*), the canonical text"*—

Thus, the **Nine Sovereigns received instruction from Fù**,
*—annotation: "九皇受傅 (Nine Sovereigns received instruction from Fù)"*—
*—annotation: "傅 (Fù), the Sage who teaches them"*—
**to seek their origin’s source**.
*—annotation: "以索其然之所生 (to seek their origin’s source)"*—
Fù is called **"one who attains Heaven’s essence."**
*—annotation: "得天之解 (attains Heaven’s essence)"*—
*—annotation: "或作天然之解 (or attains the natural essence of Heaven)"*—
**Not bound by law, nor seeking to escape law.**
*—annotation: "不与法缚 (not bound by law)"*—
*—annotation: "法 (law), the fixed principles of the cosmos"*—
*—annotation: "不求法脱 (nor seeking to escape law)"*—
Fù is called **"one who attains the beginning of Heaven and Earth."**
*—annotation: "得天地之所始 (attains the beginning of Heaven and Earth)"*—

**He generates Heaven and Earth.**
*—annotation: "生天生地 (generates Heaven and Earth)"*—
Fù is called **"the Dao/Way,"** **"the constant of attaining the Dao/Way."**
*—annotation: "傅谓之道 (Fù is called the Dao)"*—
*—annotation: "得道之常 (constant of attaining the Dao)"*—
**Not recklessly calling it constant.**
*—annotation: "不妄曰常 (not recklessly calling it constant)"*—
Fù is called **"the Sage,"**
*—annotation: "傅谓之圣人 (Fù is called the Sage)"*—
for the **Sage’s Dao/Way** aligns with **divine luminosity**,
*—annotation: "圣人之道 (Sage’s Dao)"*—
*—annotation: "与神明相得 (aligns with divine luminosity)"*—
hence it is called **"Dao/Way and virtue/power."**
*—annotation: "故曰道德 (hence it is called Dao/Way and virtue/power)"*—
**Virtue/power is what is attained by this.**
*—annotation: "德者，得此者也 (virtue/power is what is attained by this)"*—

**From the opening of *Yī* to the exhaustion of *Qì***.**
*—annotation: "郄始穷初 (From the opening of *Yī* to the exhaustion of *Qì*)"*—
*—annotation: "郄 (Yī), opening/beginning"*—
*—annotation: "始 (beginning), the initial manifestation"*—
*—annotation: "穷 (exhaustion), the end of the cycle"*—
*—annotation: "初 (Qì), primal qi, or the beginning of all"*—
As the *Lièzǐ* says:
*"The **Great Ease (Tàiyì)** is unseen qi.*
*—annotation: "太易者 (Great Ease), the most primordial state"*—
*—annotation: "未见气也 (unseen qi)"*—
*The **Great Beginning (Tàichū)** is the beginning of qi.*
*—annotation: "太初者 (Great Beginning), the first emergence of qi"*—
*The **Great Commencement (Tàishǐ)** is the beginning of form.*
*—annotation: "太始者 (Great Commencement), the first appearance of form"*—
*The **Great Purity (Tàisù)** is the beginning of substance.*
*—annotation: "太素者 (Great Purity), the primal material essence"*—
**Now Tàiyī has arrived**,
*—annotation: "太一至矣 (Tàiyī has arrived)"*—
**his realm lies between Great Ease and Great Purity**,
*—annotation: "其地盖处太易、太素之间 (his realm lies between Great Ease and Great Purity)"*—
hence it is said: **"From the opening of *Yī* to the exhaustion of *Qì*."**

**He attains the source of harmony.**
*—annotation: "得齐之所出 (attains the source of harmony)"*—
*—annotation: "帝出乎震 (the Sovereign emerges from *Zhèn*, the east)"*—
*—annotation: "齐乎巽 (harmony from *Xùn*, the southeast)"*—
For **Tàiyī** opens from *Yī* to exhaust *Qì*,
*—annotation: "太一者郄始穷初 (Tàiyī is the opening of *Yī* to the exhaustion of *Qì*)"*—
**and attains the source of harmony**,
*—annotation: "得齐之所出 (attains the source of harmony)"*—
he **can distinguish north and south**,
*—annotation: "故能北辨而南 (can distinguish north and south)"*—
**and align with all things**.
*—annotation: "与万物相见 (align with all things)"*—

The **Nine Sovereigns** held **diverse systems**,
*—annotation: "九皇殊制 (Nine Sovereigns held diverse systems)"*—
yet **their governance was all effective**,
*—annotation: "而政莫不效焉 (yet their governance was all effective)"*—
hence it is called **"Tàiyī."**
*—annotation: "故曰泰一 (hence it is called Tàiyī)"*—
**Tàiyī is without partiality**, yet **not singular**;
*—annotation: "泰一者，无适而非一也 (Tàiyī is without partiality, yet not singular)"*—
thus, the **Nine Sovereigns** held **diverse systems** yet **could not be divided**.
*—annotation: "故九皇殊制而不能二也焉 (thus, the Nine Sovereigns held diverse systems yet could not be divided)"*—

**Tàihuáng inquired of Tàiyī:**
*"Of Heaven, Earth, and human affairs—*
which is the most urgent?"*
*—annotation: "泰皇问泰一曰 (Tàihuáng inquired of Tàiyī)"*—
*—annotation: "泰皇 (Tàihuáng), likely the eldest of the Nine Sovereigns"*—
**Tàiyī replied:**
*"To cherish the vital essence**,
*—annotation: "爱精 (cherish the vital essence)"*—
**to nurture the spirit**,
*—annotation: "养神 (nurture the spirit)"*—
**and to maintain inner rectitude**—
*—annotation: "内端 (maintain inner rectitude)"*—
these are the means to **aspire toward Heaven**."
*—annotation: "所以希天 (means to aspire toward Heaven)"*—
*—annotation: "希 (aspire), emulate or align with)"*—
*"To maintain inner rectitude* is to **walk with Heaven**.
*—annotation: "内直者 (inner rectitude), uprightness within)"*—
*—annotation: "与天为徒 (walk with Heaven), act in accordance with Heaven)"*—

**Heaven** is the **root of divine luminosity**,
*—annotation: "天也者 (Heaven), indeed"*—
*—annotation: "神明之所根也 (root of divine luminosity)"*—
**refining the four seasons**,
*—annotation: "醇化四时 (refining the four seasons)"*—
*—annotation: "醇 (refining), pure and harmonious transformation)"*—
**molding the formless**,
*—annotation: "陶涎无形 (molding the formless)"*—
*—annotation: "陶 (molding), nurturing and shaping)"*—
*—annotation: "涎 (涎, *xián*), or 埏 (yáo, anding soil, blending)"*—
**yet not carving or engraving**—
*—annotation: "刻镂未萌 (not carving or engraving)"*—
*—annotation: "刻 (carving), refers to wood or earth)"*—
*—annotation: "镂 (engraving), refers to metal or stone)"*—
*—annotation: "未萌 (not yet sprouting), natural and unforced)"*—
**all this is natural**—
*—annotation: "凡此亦皆自然也 (all this is natural)"*—
how could it be **carved or sculpted by things**?
*—annotation: "夫岂物刻而雕之 (how could it be carved or sculpted by things)"*—
*—annotation: "离文 (líwén), or 作父将 (as *Fùjiāng*) or 作特然 (as *Tèrán*)"*—
*—annotation: "离 (lí), flower-like, delicate, or as a variant of *父将 (Fùjiāng)* or *特然 (Tèrán)*"*—

**Heaven’s Dao/Way initiates creation**, while **Earth fulfills it**,
*—annotation: "天道造始而地事终之 (Heaven’s Dao initiates creation, Earth fulfills it)"*—
hence his words are as such.
*—annotation: "故其言如此 (hence his words are as such)"*—
**Earth** is the one who **receives Heaven’s unfolding**,
*—annotation: "地者 (Earth), indeed"*—
*—annotation: "承天之演 (receives Heaven’s unfolding)"*—
*—annotation: "演 (unfolding), the natural process of transformation)"*—
**and bears all things to bring peace**.
*—annotation: "备载以宁者也 (bears all things to bring peace)"*—

I shall tell you the **extreme of divine luminosity**—
*—annotation: "吾将告汝神明之极 (I shall tell you the extreme of divine luminosity)"*—
Heaven, Earth, and human affairs **are unified in one**.
*—annotation: "天、地、人事三者复一也 (Heaven, Earth, and human affairs are unified in one)"*—

**First, establish the duty of lord and minister**,
*—annotation: "立置臣义 (first, establish the duty of lord and minister)"*—
*—annotation: "将 (shall), indicating intent or method)"*—
*—annotation: "从体起用 (from the body’s principles, initiate action)"*—
*—annotation: "和同天人之际 (harmonize the relationship between Heaven and humanity)"*—
*—annotation: "使之无间 (make it without separation)"*—
hence **first build the duty of lord and minister**.

The **four principles** he expounds—
*—annotation: "所陈四则 (the four principles he expounds)"*—
the **four tenets** mentioned above:
*"Fù is called one who attains Heaven’s essence,"*
*"Fù is called one who attains the beginning of Heaven and Earth,"*
*"Fù is called the constant of attaining the Dao/Way,"*
*"Fù is called the Sage"*—
are **dispersed by the eight winds**,
*—annotation: "散以八风 (dispersed by the eight winds)"*—
*—annotation: "东方曰明庶风 (east: *Míngshù* wind)"*—
*—annotation: "西方曰阊阖风 (west: *Chānghé* wind)"*—
*—annotation: "西南曰凉风 (southwest: *Liáng* wind)"*—
*—annotation: "东北曰融风 (northeast: *Róng* wind)"*—
*—annotation: "散 (dispersed), spread outward)"*—

are **summed within the six harmonies**,
*—annotation: "揆以六合 (summed within the six harmonies)"*—
*—annotation: "揆 (quí), to measure or encompass)"*—
are **applied through the four seasons**,
*—annotation: "事以四时 (applied through the four seasons)"*—
are **extended to the eight poles**,
*—annotation: "写以八极 (extended to the eight poles)"*—
*—annotation: "写 (xiě), to spread or project)"*—

are **illuminated by the three luminaries**,
*—annotation: "照以三光 (illuminated by the three luminaries)"*—
are **pastured or collected by virtue/power and punishment**,
*—annotation: "牧或作收以刑德 (pastured or collected by virtue/power and punishment)"*—
*—annotation: "收 (shōu, collected), variant of 牧 (mù, pastured
