chunks.original_text: 其亦无所不在乎？ 故曰：天、地、人事三者复一也。 日信出信入，南北有极，度之稽也。 此申致以南北之义。 冬至日在牵牛，夏至日在东井，其长短有度。 月信死信生，进退有常，数之稽也。 此申齐以晦望之义。 三五而盈，三五而阙，其损益有数。 列星不乱其行，代而或作以不干，位之稽也。 此申受以明历之义。 五位二十八舍，各有常次。 天明三以定一， 义见下文。 则万物莫不至矣#31。 或作以。 三时生长，一时煞刑，四时而定，天地尽矣。 此言方其生长则三，不后於一。 方其投刑则一，不后於三。 以明三极之道，莫知其孰急也。 夫物之始也倾倾，或作鸿鸿。 倾倾，未正之貌。 至其有也录录， 未能技於常流之中，故曰录录。 至其成形端端王王， 端端，倾倾之反。 王王，录录之反。 勿或作物损勿益，幼少随足， 各随其性而足，无事於老。 以从师俗。 仰以从於师，俯以从於俗。 毋易天生，毋散天朴。 自若则清，动之则浊。 人心譬如盘水，莫动则平，不挠则清； 微风过之，则不可以得大形之正矣。 神圣践承翼之位， 承翼之位，盖天位也。 前后曰承，左右曰翼也。 以与神皇合德； 五精之帝谓之神后，则神皇盖吴天也。 按图正端，以至无或作天极。 两治或作祭四致。 两治，上下察也。 四致，普遍四方也。 间以止或作上息。 随缘赴感，无所不周，如上所谓，可谓至矣。 然而动息则静，语息则嘿，岂常离此寂然之地哉？ 归时离气，以成万业。 离，附也。 取譬言之，借如五精之帝#32，其道各遍五方，而太吴司春，少吴司秋者，所以归时离气，以成万业也。 一来一往，视衡恒仰。 彼来此往而恒仰视车之衡，所以同乎人也。 《礼》曰：国君绥视，大夫衡视。 又曰：执天子之器则上衡，国君则平衡，大夫绥之。 或曰：衡如权衡之衡。 衡之低仰应物而已，何所容其心哉。 五官六府，分之有道。 无钩无绳，浑沌不分。 曲者不以钩，直者不以绳，而浑沌全矣。 故曰：擢六律，塞师旷之耳； 散五采，胶离朱之目； 毁绝钩绳，俪工倕之指，而天下人始合其朴矣。 大象不成，事无经法。 精神相薄，乃伤百族。 此明浑沌之不可判也。 盖伪生真死而浑沌判矣，则精神相战，百族为之不宁。 《南华》曰：上倍日月之明，下烁山川之神。 盖谓是乎？ 偷气相或为祖时，后功可立。 盗阴阳之和以载其形，而还以相时。 先定其利，待物自至， 不迎。 素次以法。 物至辄合法者，天地之正器也。 用法不正，玄德不成。 所谓：乱天之经，逆物之情，玄天弗成。 上圣者，与天地接， 句。 结六或作交连而不解者也， 六连，六合也。 《老子》曰：善结者无绳，约而不可解。 是故有道。 南面执政，以卫神明，左右前后，静侍或无侍字中央。 此言君无为也，而臣亦无为。 开原流洋， 洋，若今海之有洋也。 精微往来、倾倾绳绳，或作鸿鶁绳绳。 倾倾，侧貌。 绳绳，正貌。 内持以维，外纽以纲或作经，行以理埶或作执，纪以终始，同一殊职， 联之使同，统之使一。 立为明官五范。 五范，五音也。 义见下文。 四时各以类相从#33，昧或作味玄生色， 春夏之华，发於玄冬。 音声相衡。 衡，平也。 东方者，万物立止焉，或作东方生物图揭立止焉。
chunks.translated_text:
The **Dao/Way** is nowhere absent—
Thus it is said: **Heaven, Earth, and human affairs** are but one in three.

The **Sun** is trustworthy in rising and setting,
With **South and North** having their limits—
This measures the **extremes of direction**.
The **Moon** is trustworthy in death and rebirth,
Advancing and retreating with constancy—
This verifies the **cycles of time**.
When **three fives** are full, when **three fives** are void,
Their **gain and loss** follow a fixed measure.
The **stars** do not stray in their courses,
Alternating in succession without interference—
This confirms the **order of celestial positions**.

The **Twenty-Eight Mansions**, five stations each,
Each with its fixed sequence.
**Heaven’s clarity** is defined by **three** to establish **one**—
*(Explanation follows in the text below.)*
Thus, all things attain their fullness.

Or it is said: **Three times** for growth and lengthening,
**One time** for decline and punishment,
And in **four seasons**, all is settled—
Heaven and Earth are complete.
When things **grow and lengthen**, it is **three**—
Not delayed by **one**.
When they **succumb to punishment**, it is **one**—
Not delayed by **three**.
Thus, the **threefold Dao/Way** is revealed—
None know which is more urgent.

At their **beginning**, things are **tilted and uneven**,
*(Or: vast and boundless.)*
**Tilted and uneven**—the form not yet upright.
When they **take shape**, they are **strained and constrained**,
*(Unable yet to flow with the constant current, hence "strained.")*
When they **achieve form**, they are **upright and sovereign**,
*(Upright—opposite of tilted; sovereign—opposite of constrained.)*
**Do not**—*(or: "Let not")*—**deplete or augment**,
**Youth suffices**—each follows its nature fully,
Without need for aging.
**Above**, follow the **Teacher**;
**Below**, follow the **common ways**.
Do not alter **Heaven’s birth**,
Do not scatter **Heaven’s purity**.
**Stillness** brings clarity,
**Movement** brings turbidity.
The **human heart** is like water in a basin—
If undisturbed, it is level;
If unperturbed, it is clear.
But even a **gentle breeze** passing over it
Makes it impossible to restore its original form.

The **Divine Sovereign** treads the **Winged Position**—
*(The Winged Position: the Heavenly realm.)*
**Before and behind** are **supported**,
**Left and right** are **winged**.
To **align with the Divine Emperor** in **virtue/power**;
*(The Five Celestial Deities are called the Divine Sovereigns; thus, the Divine Emperor refers to the Great Brilliant One.)*
**Adjust the diagram’s center** to reach the **Heavenly Pole**.
**Twofold governance**—*(or: "Upper and lower scrutiny")*—
**Fourfold extension**—*(universal reach to the four quarters.)*
**Intermittent cessation**—*(or: "Upper stillness").*
Responding to **conditions and sensations** without omission,
As previously stated—this is **perfection**.

Yet **movement ceases in stillness**,
**Speech ceases in silence**—
How could one **constantly depart** from this **tranquil state**?

**Returning to the times**, **separating the qi**,
To **fulfill myriad affairs**.
*(Separating: adhering.)*
Take, for example, the **Five Celestial Deities**—
Each **Dao/Way** pervades the five directions,
Yet the **Great Brilliant One** governs **Spring**,
The **Lesser Brilliant One** governs **Autumn**—
Thus, **returning to the times**, **separating the qi**,
To **fulfill myriad affairs**.

**Coming and going**, **observing the balance**—
*(Like a chariot’s yoke, ever upright.)*
**They come here, depart there**, yet **constantly uphold the balance**—
Thus, they align with humanity.
*The Rites say:*
"The **King of the State** gazes with **calm composure**,
The **Great Officer** gazes with **measured balance**."
It is also said:
"When holding the **Son of Heaven’s instruments**, the gaze is **upright**;
When the **King of the State** holds them, the gaze is **level**;
When the **Great Officer** holds them, the gaze is **calm**."
Or it is said: **"Balance"**—like the **beam of a steelyard**—
Its **rise and fall** respond to things—
What room is there for the **heart** to interfere?

The **Five Organs and Six Palaces**,
Their **allocation** follows **Dao/Way**.
Without **hooks or cords**,
In **primordial unity**, undivided.
The **crooked** need no **hooks**,
The **straight** need no **cords**—
Yet **primordial unity** remains whole.
Thus it is said:
**Pluck the six pitches**—
**Blind** the ears of **Shī Guāng**;
**Scatter the five hues**—
**Glue shut** the eyes of **Lí Zhū**;
**Destroy all hooks and cords**—
**Pair the fingers** of **Gōng Tú**—
And only then will **all under Heaven** return to their **primordial simplicity**.

When the **Great Form** is not yet complete,
**Affairs lack structure**.
**Spirits** clash—
And **hundreds of clans** are harmed.
This reveals that **primordial unity** must not be **severed**.

For when **artifice** arises and **truth** dies,
**Primordial unity** is **divided**—
Then **spirits** contend,
And **hundreds of clans** are restless.
*The South华 says:*
"Above, **outshining the brilliance of sun and moon**,
Below, **piercing the spirits of mountains and rivers**."
Does this not refer to this?

**Stealing the harmony of yin and yang** to **sustain their forms**,
Yet **returning** to **align with the times**.
First **determine their advantage**,
Then **await**—**without forcing**—
**Things will come of their own accord**.
**Follow the natural order** with **law**.
When things arrive, they **conform to law**—
This is the **proper instrument of Heaven and Earth**.
If **law is not applied correctly**,
**Mysterious virtue/power** cannot be achieved.
As it is said:
"To **disrupt Heaven’s patterns**,
To **contradict the nature of things**—
**Mysterious Heaven** will not be fulfilled."

The **Supreme Sage** interfaces with **Heaven and Earth**,
*(Sentence structure: "interfaces" as in **interlocking and unbroken**—
Six connections, the **Six Harmonies**.)*
As *Laozi* says:
"The **skilled binder** uses no cords,
Yet **tightly bound**, it cannot be undone."
Thus, **Dao/Way** is achieved.

**Facing south**, holding **governance**,
To **guard the Divine Clarity**—
**Left, right, front, back**,
**Stillness**—*(or: "without attendance")*—**at the center**.
This speaks of the **Sovereign’s non-action**,
While the **ministers** also **do not act**.

**Opening the original flow**, vast as the **ocean’s expanse**,
*(Ocean: like the modern term "洋," the boundless sea.)*
**Subtle essences** flow to and fro—
**Tilted and uneven**, **strained and constrained**,
*(Or: vast and boundless, **strained and constrained**.)*
**Internally**, held by **threads**,
**Externally**, knotted by **ropes**—*(or: "threads")*—
**Guided by principle**, **grasped by end and beginning**,
**Uniting the disparate**, **harmonizing the singular**,
Establishing **five clear officials**—
*(The five officials: the five tones.)*
**Four seasons**, each following their **kind**,
**Tasting the Mysterious**—*(or: "reveling in the Mysterious")*—**to produce color**,
*(The blossoms of spring and summer emerge from the **Mysterious Winter**.)*
**Sounds** are **balanced**—*(balanced: level.)*
The **Eastern Direction**—
Here, **all things stand and cease**.

chunks.original_text: 止，犹植也。 故调以征。 南方者，万物华羽焉，故调以羽。 西方者，万物成章焉，故调以商。 北方者，万物录藏焉，故调以角。 征属南方，而今此言於东方者，以调东方而已，非谓分配东方也。 下皆放此。 中央者，太一之位， 北极，天地之中，而其一明者，太一之座。 百神仰制焉，故调以宫。 道以为先， 夫道至矣，而更推以为先。 《记》曰：夫礼，必本於太一，分而为天地，转而为阴阳。 举载神明，华天上扬，或作华物天上。 疑此乐章之名，盖若《皇华》、《析扬》也。 本出黄锺，所始为东方； 万物唯隆。 以木华物，天下尽木也，使居东方，主春。 以火照物，天下尽火也，使居南方，主夏。 以金割物，天下尽金也，使居西方，主秋。 以水沉物，天下尽水也，使居北方，主冬。 土为大都，天下尽土也，使居中央，守地。 天下尽人也，以天子为正。 此言太一司天而分任五方，又以天子治之。 调其气， 调其五行之气。 木温、金清之类#35。 和其味， 和其五行之味。 水咸、火苦之类。 听其声， 火焦、金杀之类。 正其形， 木圆、土方之类。 迭往观今，或作令。 故业可循或作修也。 天下一致，来不异古，往不异今，却而观之，则其业可循。 《近迭》篇曰：师未发轫而兵可迭也。 盖前却曰迭。 首尾易面，或作向#36。 春夏先，秋冬后，其方各有向焉，何可易也。 地理离经， 天之首尾易向，则地理亦失其经。 夺爱令乱。 夺其所欲而乱。 盖天序易於上，地理离於下，则人其有不乱者乎？ 上灭天文，理不可知， 天文灭矣，地理安可知也。 故曰：文理相明者也。 神明失。 或作夫。 从或作徒文域作父理者，相明者也。 色味者，相度者也。 藻华者，相成者也。 对质曰藻，对实曰华。 藻，文也。 藻如草之藻，华如木之华。 众者，我而众之，故可以一范请也。 请，如请益之请。 盖众者自我而千万，则其一之亦在我矣。 请以一范，无不可者。

「Stop, just like planting.
Thus, the **tuning** is with **Zheng**—
The **Southern Direction**, where all things bloom with **feathers**,
Thus, the **tuning** is with **Yu**—
The **Western Direction**, where all things form **patterns**,
Thus, the **tuning** is with **Shang**—
The **Northern Direction**, where all things **record and store**,
Thus, the **tuning** is with **Jue**—
Though **Zheng** belongs to the **Southern Direction**, this **tuning** is applied to the **Eastern Direction** alone,
Not to assign it to the **Eastern Direction** itself.
*(All the following cases are similarly treated.)*
The **Central Direction**, the **position of Taiyi**—
The **Northern Pole**, the **center of Heaven and Earth**,
And its **single luminous point**, the **seat of Taiyi**.
All **spirits** look up to it for **regulation**,
Thus, the **tuning** is with **Gong**—
**Dao** is taken as the **foundation**,
For **Dao** is supreme,
Yet it is further **advanced** as the **foundation**.
The *Records* say:
**Rites**, indeed, originate from **Taiyi**,
And are divided into **Heaven and Earth**,
Transformed into **yin and yang**.
They **elevate and load** the **spirit-brightness**,
Bloom in **Heaven** and **ascend**—
*(Or: "Bloom in all things and ascend to Heaven.")*
Perhaps the name of this **musical chapter** is like *Huanghua* or *Xiyang*.
It **originates** from the **Yellow Bell**,
Beginning with the **Eastern Direction**—
*(All things here **thrive**.)*
With **wood** blooming all things,
The world is **all wood**,
So it is placed in the **Eastern Direction**, presiding over **Spring**.
With **fire** illuminating all things,
The world is **all fire**,
So it is placed in the **Southern Direction**, presiding over **Summer**.
With **metal** cutting all things,
The world is **all metal**,
So it is placed in the **Western Direction**, presiding over **Autumn**.
With **water** sinking all things,
The world is **all water**,
So it is placed in the **Northern Direction**, presiding over **Winter**.
**Earth** is the **great capital**,
The world is **all earth**,
So it is placed in the **Central Direction**, guarding the **land**.
The world is **all people**,
And the **Son of Heaven** is the **proper ruler**.
This means **Taiyi** governs **Heaven** and delegates authority to the **five directions**,
And the **Son of Heaven** administers them.
**Adjusting its qi**—
Adjusting the **qi of the five phases**.
*(Examples: **wood** as warm, **metal** as cool.)*
**Balancing its flavors**—
*(Balancing the flavors of the five phases.)*
*(Examples: **water** as salty, **fire** as bitter.)*
**Hearing its sounds**—
*(Examples: **fire** as sharp, **metal** as harsh.)*
**Rectifying its forms**—
*(Examples: **wood** as round, **earth** as square.)*
**Alternatingly observing the past and present**—
*(Or: "Commanding.")*
Thus, **affairs** can be **followed**—
*(Or: "practiced.")*
**Heaven and Earth** are in **harmony**,
The **past** does not differ from **ancient times**,
The **present** does not differ from **today**,
And when **retrospectively observed**, its **affairs** can be **followed**.
The *Chapter on Near Alternation* says:
*"The teacher has not yet set out, yet the troops can be ordered to march."*
*(This likely refers to the earlier term "alternatingly.")*
The **head and tail** of **Heaven** **reverse their orientation**—
*(Or: "face.")*
**Spring and Summer** come first,
**Autumn and Winter** come after,
Each **direction** has its **orientation**,
How can it be **reversed**?
If the **principles of Earth** **deviate from the classics**,
Then **Heaven’s head and tail reverse their orientation**,
And the **principles of Earth** will **lose their classics**.
**Seize what they love and bring disorder**.
Seize what they desire and **disorder** ensues.
If the **sequence of Heaven** is **disrupted above**,
And the **principles of Earth** **deviate below**,
Then will there be any **humans** who remain **orderly**?
If **Heaven’s patterns** are **extinguished above**,
Then **principles** cannot be **known**.
If **Heaven’s patterns** are **extinguished**, how can the **principles of Earth** be **known**?
Thus, it is said:
**"Patterns and principles mutually illuminate each other."**
**Spirit-brightness** is **lost**.
*(Or: "If.")*
**Deviating from the classics**—
*(Or: "mere patterns")*—**reversing principles**—
*(Or: "fatherly principles")*—
These are the ones that **mutually illuminate**.
**Colors and flavors** are **mutually measured**,
**Ornament and bloom** are **mutually completed**,
*"Ornament"* refers to **patterns**,
*"Ornament"* like the **stems of grass**,
*"Bloom"* like the **flowers of wood**.
The **many**—
If the **many** originate from **my self**,
Then they can be **unified** with a **single standard**.
*(Standard: **Gong**.)*
**Request**—
*(Request: as in "ask for further instruction.")*
If the **many** originate from **my self** and number in the **thousands and ten-thousands**,
Then even their **unification** lies within **my self**.
**Request** with a **single standard**,
And there is **nothing** that cannot be **accomplished**.

chunks.original_text: 顺爱之政，殊类相或作未通； 《列子》曰：虎之与人异类而媚养己者，顺也。 逆爱之政，同类相亡。 《传》曰：焉知父子不为豺狼。 故圣人立天为父，建地为母，范或作危者非务使云必同，知一期或作明以使一人也。 泛错之天地之间，而人人被其和。 或作人被其和。 此言圣人盖知一期以使一人，而惟是心焉。 泛错之天地之间，而人人被其和也，非务使之必同。 故曰：一人之情，千万人之情是也。 和也者，无形而有味者也。 和者，道也。 盖道无形而有味。 同和者，仁也。 与道同和。 相容或作密者，义也。 与道相容者，义也。 盖不道则义不能容，不义则道不能容。 仁义者，所乐同或作自名或作召也。 能同或作因所乐，无形内政， 此言能同仁义之乐，则政法虽有而真空内之。 盖所谓真空者，无不碍有故也。 故圣知神方，调於无形，而物莫不从。 天，受藻华以为神明之根者也。 天受道之英华，以生神明。 《列子》曰：清轻者上为天，重浊者下为地。 地，受时或作得以为万物原者也。 地者，受天之时以产万物。 神圣，详或作祥理、或无详理二字，作庠恶。 深契於理。 恶离制命之柄、制命之柄或无离字。 《老子》所谓：鱼不可脱於渊，利器不可以示人。 敛散华精以慰地责或作箦#37天者也。 此言神圣契理而有以制命，则齑粉万物而不为戾，虽以慰地责天，可也。 昔者老子上毁五帝、通及三皇，而西域之学有喝佛骂祖者，岂近是' 乎？ 调味、章色、正声，以定天、地、人事三者，毕此矣。 其道如上所谓，则天、地、人事岂有出於此乎？ 泰录第十一 入论泰鸿之内，出观神明之外，定制泰一之衷， 衷之言，中也。 无所出入为定。 以为物稽。 入而论泰鸿之内，出而观神明之外，定而制泰一之衷，便物取稽焉。 天有九鸿， 《拾遗记》曰：望三壶如聚米，视八鸿若萦带。 说者以为：八鸿，八方之名。 鸿，鸿大也。 然则九鸿盖九围欤？ 地有九州， 此即邹子所谓九州，盖非禹别者也。 泰一之道，九皇之傅，请成於泰始之末。 泰一之道至矣，故上篇云：九皇受傅，以索其然之所生。 而今此又言其傅尝请成於泰始，盖非泰始莫足以知焉。 其曰末者，言顺下风而请也。 见不或无不字详事於名理之外， 此言才见其事之略而已，更当要其会归。 故下文云。 范无形，尝无味，以要名理之所会。 范者，味之正也。 范者，形也。 正，如覆怨其正之正。 盖形受养於味者也。 味者，气之父母也。 气不足，补之以精。 精不足，补之以味。 精或作清微者，天地之始或作所治也。 言形、言味而又言此者，盖将要名理之所会，又当致此三者也。 不或无不字见形脔而天下归美焉， 脔，肉也。 名尸神明者，大道是或作正也。 夫错行合意，扶义本仁，或作收。 积顺之所成，先圣之所生也。 行其道者有其名，为其事者有其功。 此言仁义之治，故行其道者有其名，为其事者有其功。 若夫圣人无名，神人无功，乘於道德而游乎万物之上，则岂局於仁义之域哉。 故下文云。 故天地成於元或作无气，万物乘於天地， 元气，太虚也。 太虚含天地，天地含万物，故其言如此。 神圣乘或作秉於道德， 《南华》所谓无訾无誉、一龙一蛇者也。 以究其理。 或云：万物乘於圣，秉於道德，以救其圣神#38，以究天地万物之理。

「The governance of **affectionate compliance** *(Or: "politics of harmonious love")*—**distinct types mutually accommodate** *(Or: "diverse natures find mutual harmony")*;
*The Liezi* states: *"The tiger and man differ in kind, yet if the tiger curries favor with those who nourish it, that is compliance."*

The governance of **contrary compliance**—**same types mutually perish** *(Or: "like natures mutually annihilate")*.
*The Classic of Transmission* says: *"How do we know that father and son will not become wolves and jackals?"*
Thus, the **Sage** establishes **Heaven as Father** and **Earth as Mother**,
*(Or: "Heaven as Father, Earth as Mother")*—
not to **force** *(Or: "compel")* all to be **identical** *(Or: "the same")*,
but to **know the singular principle** *(Or: "the unified Dao")*
so as to **harmonize one person** *(Or: "guide a single individual")*.

**Permeating** *(Or: "Wandering freely")* **erratically** *(Or: "without fixed bounds")*
between **Heaven and Earth**,
yet **every person** is **enveloped** *(Or: "encompassed")* by its **harmony**.
*(Or: "everyone is nourished by its concord.")*
This means the **Sage** **knows the singular principle** to **harmonize one person**,
and **only the heart** is thus.
*(Or: "yet only the heart is the key.")*

**Permeating** *(Or: "Wandering freely")* **erratically** between **Heaven and Earth**,
every person is **enveloped** by its **harmony**,
not to **force** them to be **identical**.
Thus it is said:
*"The emotion of one person—
that is the emotion of thousands and ten-thousands of people."*

**Harmony** is **formless yet imbued with flavor** *(Or: "taste")*.
**Harmony** is **the Dao**.
Indeed, **the Dao** is **formless yet imbued with flavor**.

**Conformity to harmony** is **Ren** *(Or: "benevolence")*.
**Conformity with the Dao’s harmony**—
**mutual accommodation** *(Or: "intimate closeness")*—is **Yi** *(Or: "righteousness")*.
**Conformity with the Dao’s harmony**—
**mutual accommodation**—is **Yi**.
Indeed, **without the Dao**, **Yi** cannot **accommodate** *(Or: "hold sway")*,
and **without Yi**, **the Dao** cannot **accommodate**.
**Ren and Yi** are **what one delights in** *(Or: "the shared essence of self-naming")*—
**what one delights in** *(Or: "the self-called")*—
**formless internal governance** *(Or: "internalized law")*.
This means: **if one conforms to the delight of Ren and Yi**,
then **government and law**, though they exist, are **truly void within**.
*(Or: "the true emptiness of the heart.")*
Indeed, **what is called "true emptiness"** *(Or: "true void")*—
**that is because there is nothing that does not allow for existence** *(Or: "nothing that hinders being")*.

Thus, the **Sage** **knows the divine method** *(Or: "the divine plan")*,
**adjusting** *(Or: "harmonizing")* **without form**,
and **all things** follow accordingly.
**Heaven** receives **breath and bloom** *(Or: "the vital essence of patterns and splendor")*
as the **root of divine luminosity** *(Or: "the origin of Heaven’s brilliance")*.
**Heaven** receives **the Dao’s vital essence**,
thus **giving birth to divine luminosity**.
*The Liezi* states:
*"The clear and light ascend to become Heaven,
the heavy and turbid descend to become Earth."*

**Earth** receives **time** *(Or: "seasons")*
as the **source of all things**.
**Earth** receives **Heaven’s seasons** to **bear all things**.

**Divine Saints** *(Or: "The Sage and the Divine")*—
*(Or: "The Sage and the Divine, who deeply grasp the principles")*—
*(Or: "The Sage and the Divine, who deeply grasp the principles")*—
**are distant from the grasp of command** *(Or: "hold no sway over life and death")*.
*(Or: "The grasp of command: perhaps omitting *‘are distant from’*")*
*The Laozi* says:
*"Fish cannot be taken from the deep,
sharp tools cannot be shown to the people."*

**Concentrating and dispersing** *(Or: "Refining and dispersing")*
**vital essence and splendor** *(Or: "the vital breath and refined essence")*
to **soothe Earth’s burden** *(Or: "assuage Heaven’s responsibility")*—
*(Or: "to assuage Heaven’s responsibility to Earth")*—
this is **the Divine Sage’s way**.
This means: **the Divine Sage deeply grasps the principles**,
and **thus has means to govern life and death**,
yet **grinds all things to dust** *(Or: "reduces them to powder")* **without causing harm**,
though **soothing Earth’s burden** *(Or: "assuaging Heaven’s responsibility")*—
it is **possible**.

In ancient times, **Laozi** ascended to **destroy the Five Emperors** *(Or: "overthrow the Five Sovereigns")*,
**reaching back to the Three Sovereigns** *(Or: "extending to the Three August Ones")*,
yet **Western Domain’s** *(Or: "the Western Regions’")* **scholars** have **those who shout Buddha and curse the Ancestors**,
are they **near this truth**?
*(Or: "are they close to this?")*

**Adjusting flavors, refining colors, rectifying sounds**,
to **establish** the **three affairs of Heaven, Earth, and Man**—
this is **complete**.

If **the Dao** is as **above** *(Or: "as stated earlier")*,
then **Heaven, Earth, and Man’s affairs**—
how could they **transcend this**?

**The Grand Concordance, Chapter Eleven** *(Or: "The Grand Concordance, Section Eleven")*—
**Entering to discuss the Grand Abyss within** *(Or: "the vastness of the Great Void")*,
**exiting to observe the divine luminosity without**,
**establishing the measure of the Grand Unity’s core**—
*(Or: "the core of the Grand One")*—
**core** *(Or: "the word ‘core’")*—**the central** *(Or: "the middle")*.
**To have no exit nor entry is to establish** *(Or: "the fixed point")*.
**This is to govern all things** *(Or: "to make them conform")*.

**Entering to discuss the Grand Abyss within**,
**exiting to observe the divine luminosity without**,
**establishing the measure of the Grand Unity’s core**—
**this governs all things** *(Or: "to make them conform")*.

**Heaven** has **nine expanses** *(Or: "nine vast regions")*.
*The Record of Lost Recollections* says:
*"Gazing at three cauldrons like heaped rice,
beholding eight expanses as winding belts."*
Scholars say:
*"Eight expanses—
the eight directions’ names.
**Expanses**—**vast and grand** *(Or: "the word ‘expanses’ means ‘vast and grand’")*.
Thus, **the nine expanses** are **perhaps nine encircling regions**?"

**Earth** has **nine provinces**—
*(Or: "this is what Master Zhou [Zhou Dunyi] called the nine provinces")*—
**not the same as Yu’s division**.

**The Grand Unity’s Dao** *(Or: "The Dao of the Grand One")*—
**the transmission of the Nine Sovereigns** *(Or: "the teachings of the Nine August Ones")*—
**I request** *(Or: "I ask")* **its completion at the end of the Grand Beginning** *(Or: "the Grand Origin")*.

**The Grand Unity’s Dao** is **perfected** *(Or: "complete")*,
thus the **upper section** *(Or: "previous chapter")* says:
*"The Nine Sovereigns receive transmission,
to trace where their **‘thusness’** *(Or: "‘so-being’")* originates."*
And now it is said again:
*"Their transmission was perhaps completed at the Grand Beginning"*—
**indeed, without the Grand Beginning, one cannot truly know it**.
The **‘end’**—
**this means to comply with the lower winds and request** *(Or: "to follow the lower currents and ask")*.

**Seeing** *(Or: "Upon seeing")*—
*(Or: "Perhaps omitting *‘seeing’*")*—**the details beyond mere names and principles**,
this means: **only the outline is revealed**,
**yet more must be sought in their convergence**.
Thus the **following text** says:

**Governing without form** *(Or: "The formless standard")*,
**adjusting without flavor** *(Or: "The flavorless adjustment")*—
to **seek the convergence of names and principles**.
**Governing**—**the rectification of form**.
**Adjusting**—**flavor**.
**Rectification**—as in *"covering grievances with their rectification"*—
**this means form is nourished by flavor**.

**Flavor**—**the parent of qi** *(Or: "the parent and mother of qi")*.
If **qi** is insufficient, **supplement it with essence**.
If **essence** is insufficient, **supplement it with flavor**.
**Essence**—*(Or: "perhaps omitting ‘essence’")*—**the subtle and clear** *(Or: "the pure and refined")*—
**the beginning of Heaven and Earth** *(Or: "the origin of Heaven and Earth’s transformation")*.

**Speaking of form, speaking of flavor, yet also speaking of this**—
**this is to seek the convergence of names and principles**,
and **also to attain these three things**.

**Seeing** *(Or: "Perhaps omitting *‘seeing’*")*—**form ground into mincemeat** *(Or: "form butchered")*,
**yet all under Heaven call it beautiful**—
**this is the Great Dao** *(Or: "the right path")*.

**Erratic movement** *(Or: "Misaligned actions")*—**harmonizing intentions** *(Or: "uniting wills")*,
**supporting righteousness** *(Or: "upholding Yi’s foundation")*—**Ren is its root** *(Or: "its origin is Ren")*.
**Accumulating what compliance brings** *(Or: "The accumulated fruit of compliance")*—
**this is what the ancient Sages produced**.

**Those who walk the Dao** have **its name**,
**those who perform its deeds** have **its function**.
This means: **the governance of Ren and Yi**,
thus **those who walk the Dao** have **its name**,
**those who perform its deeds** have **its function**.

If **the Sage** has **no name**,
and **the Divine Person** has **no function**,
**riding upon virtue and power** *(Or: "surfing the Dao and its transformations")*,
**wandering freely above all things**—
then **how could they be confined to the domain of Ren and Yi**?

Thus the **following text** says:
Hence, **Heaven and Earth** are **completed in the Original Qi** *(Or: "the Primordial Void")*,
and **all things** **ride upon Heaven and Earth**,
**Original Qi**—**the Great Emptiness** *(Or: "the Grand Primordial")*.
The **Great Emptiness** contains **Heaven and Earth**,
**Heaven and Earth** contain **all things**,
thus **its words** are such.

**Divine Saints** **ride upon** *(Or: "hold fast to")* **virtue and power**,
*(Or: "as in *Zhuangzi*’s ‘without blame or praise, like a dragon or a snake’")*—
to **investigate their principles**.
*(Or: "Perhaps: ‘to rescue their divine essence, to investigate the principles of Heaven, Earth, and all things.’")*

chunks.original_text: 若上圣皇天者，先圣之所倚威立有命也。 尧、舜、三代诰命未尝不称天者，盖以倚威立命而已。 若夫致治之自，则岂可以取赖於天哉？ 是在我者也。 此纣之矫诬上帝而无益於乱。 故下文云。 故致治之自在己者也。 招高者高，招庳者库。 此言治之污隆，顾我所以招之如何。 未有囿於管、晏之卑，而可以招尧、舜之高者也。 故成形而不变者，度也； 未离己而在彼者，狎沤也#39。 如狎沤者，心动於内则沤乌舞而不下，此未离己而在彼者也。 陈体立节，万世不易，天地之位也。 分物纪或作他名，文理明#40别，神圣之齐也。 齐，如齐量之齐。 法天居地，去方错圆，或作督。 方以智则滞，圆而神则通。 神圣之鉴也。 象说名物， 拟之者，象也。 议之者，说也。 成功遂事，隐彰不相离， 神圣之教，不即不离，而至妙之所会者更粗，至高之所适者反下。 隐显岂相离哉。 神圣之教也。 天一位，地一位，圣人参於两间以齐。 齐之而以彼鉴此，以此教彼，则天下之理得矣。 然后万物各遂其生。 故下文云。 故流分而神生， 流分，谓水也。 天一生水，其於物为精。 精聚而后神从之。 动登而明生， 动登，谓火也。 地二生火，其於物为神。 神会而后识从之。 明见而形成，形成而功存。 故文者，所以分物也； 理者，所以纪或作地名也。 天地者，同事而异域者也。 天域於上，地域於下。 无规圆者，天之文也。 无矩方者，地之理也。 天循文以动，地循理以作者也。 二端或作圣端者、神之法也。 神明之法，如是而已。 神圣之人后或作命，先天地而尊者也。 后天地生，然知天地之始； 先天地亡，然知天地之终。 道包之； 故能知度之； 其道围乎天地之外，故知能知之，义能度之。 尊重焉，故能改动或无动字之； 拔阴阳，移寒暑。 敏或作数明焉，故能制断之。 敏，或为数。 精神者，物之贵大者也； 精神之外，皆其绪余土直者也。 内圣者， 或作圣内。 精神之原也。 外王者乃其绪余土直，则内圣者精神之原也。 莫贵焉，故靡不仰制焉。 制者，所以卫精、擢神、致气也。 精欲啬，神欲养，气欲专，故其辞如此。 擢者，秀拔之辞。 幽则不泄，蕳或作闻则不烦，不烦则精明达， 明太用则昏，精太用则竭。 故能役贤能，使神明， 无为也，故能用天下而有余。 百化随而变，终始从而豫。 豫，暇豫也。 神明者，积精微全粹之所成也。 圣道神方，或作万。 要之极也。 要其会归，至於此而极矣。 帝制神化，治之期也。 至矣，尽矣，不可以有加矣。 故师或无师字为君而学为臣， 教者为君，学者为臣。 上贤为天子，次贤为三公，高为诸侯。 高者以为诸侯。 易姓而王，不以祖或作礼籍为君者，欲同一善之安也。 尧授舜，舜#41授禹，用此道也。 彼天地动作於胸中，然后事成於外； 万物出入焉，然后或作然同生物无害。 圣人心外无法而气合於神，神合於无。 天地之大，万物之多，动作出入反在於胸中，则事岂有不成，物岂有不利哉？ 闿阖四时，引移阴阳，怨没澄物， 疑。 天下以为自然， 百姓谓我自然是也。 此神圣之所以绝众也。 子贡曰：仲尼，天也，不可阶而升也。 圣原神文，有验而不可见者也。 有情有性，无为无形。 故过人可见、绝人未远也，
chunks.translated_text:
If the **Supreme Sage**—the **August Heavenly Sovereign**—is the **First Sage’s** foundation of **威威** *(威: awe/authority)* and **establishment of command**,
then **Emperor Yao, Emperor Shun, and the Three Dynasties’** edicts never failed to invoke **Heaven**—
for they relied solely on **威威** and **command**.

But when it comes to **achieving governance** in its own right,
how could it depend on **Heaven**?
This is something **within oneself**.
This is how **King Zhou** falsely invoked **the Supreme Deity** to no avail in his chaos.

Thus the **following text** says:
**Achieving governance** lies within oneself.
**Summon the lofty**, and it rises;
**summon the lowly**, and it descends.
This speaks of governance’s **corruption or flourishing**—
it depends on how **one summons it**.

There has never been one **confined to the humility of Guan Zhong and Yan Ying**
who could summon the **loftiness of Yao and Shun**.

Thus, **what is formed yet unchanging** is **measure** *(度)*;
**what remains external yet within oneself** is **familiarity with chaos** *(狎沤)*#39.
As in **familiarity with chaos**—
when the heart stirs within, the **chaos-black** *(沤乌)* dances yet does not descend—
this is **what remains external yet within oneself**.

**Establishing form and principle** unaltered for ten thousand generations—
this is the **position of Heaven and Earth**.
**Distinguishing things by name**, with **patterns and principles clearly marked**—
this is the **harmony of the Divine Saints**.
*Harmony*, as in **leveling measures**.

**Conforming to Heaven, dwelling on Earth**,
**abandoning the square, embracing the round** *(or: **supervising**)*#40.
The **square** by **intelligence** becomes **obstructed**,
the **round** by **spirit** becomes **flowing**.
This is the **mirror of the Divine Saints**.

**Embodied forms and named things**—
**imitating them** is **embodiment** *(象)*,
**discussing them** is **explanation** *(说)*.
**Accomplishing deeds and completing affairs**—
**hidden and manifest** never separate—
the **teaching of the Divine Saints**,
**neither immediate nor distant**,
yet where **the utmost subtlety converges**, the **coarsest** prevails;
where **the utmost height reaches**, the **lowest** returns.
**Hidden and manifest**—how could they separate?
This is the **teaching of the Divine Saints**.

**Heaven** holds one position,
**Earth** holds one position,
and the **Sage harmonizes** between the two.
**Harmonizing**, using **one to mirror the other**,
using **this to teach that**—
then the **principles of the world** are attained.

Only then do **all things fulfill their nature**.
Thus the **following text** says:
**When the flow divides, spirit is born**—
*Flow divides* refers to **water**.
**Heaven’s One** generates **water**,
and its **essence** in things is **precision**.
**Precision** gathers, then **spirit** follows.

**When movement ascends, clarity is born**—
*Movement ascends* refers to **fire**.
**Earth’s Two** generates **fire**,
and its **spirit** in things is **divine essence**.
**Divine essence** converges, then **awareness** follows.

**Clarity reveals form**,
**form establishes function**.
Thus, **patterns** are what **distinguishes things**,
**principles** are what **names or records them**#40.
**Heaven and Earth** are **cooperative yet distinct in domain**—
**Heaven’s domain** is above,
**Earth’s domain** is below.
**Without a compass**, the **round** is **Heaven’s pattern**,
**without a square**, the **straight** is **Earth’s principle**.
**Heaven** follows **patterns** in motion,
**Earth** follows **principles** in creation.
These two **ends** *(or: **Sage-ends**)* are **the law of spirit**#41.
The **law of spirit and clarity** is as such.

The **Sage-person**—
**later than Heaven and Earth yet more honored**—
**later than Heaven and Earth in birth**,
yet **knows their beginning**;
**earlier than Heaven and Earth in death**,
yet **knows their end**.
**The Way** encompasses them;
thus **they know measure**;
their **Way** encircles **outside Heaven and Earth**,
so **they know what can be known**,
**what can be measured**.
**Honored and weighty**,
they **can alter motion** *(or: **without motion**)*;
**transcend yin and yang**, **shift cold and heat**.
**Keen** *(or: **numerous**)* in **clarity**,
they **can judge and decide**.
**Spirit-essence** is the **most noble and vast** of things;
**outside spirit-essence**, all else is **its residual dross**.
**Inner Sagehood** is the **source of spirit-essence**;
**outer kingship** is its **residual dross**.
Thus **Inner Sagehood** is the **source of spirit-essence**—
none is more noble, so **all defer to its governance**.
**Governance** is what **protects essence, elevates spirit, and refines qi**.
**Essence** desires **frugality**,
**spirit** desires **nurturing**,
**qi** desires **unity**—
thus the **language** is as such.
*Elevate* means **to excel and surpass**.

**Secluded**, it does not **leak**;
**heard**, it does not **weary**—
not wearying, **essence and clarity** reach through.
**Clarity overused** becomes **dim**,
**essence overused** becomes **exhausted**.
Thus they **command the capable**,
**make them spirit-bright**—
**without action**,
they **can employ the world with surplus**.
**Hundred transformations** follow and change,
**beginning and end** proceed and **foresee**#42.
*Foresee* means **leisurely ease**.

**Spirit-clarity** is the **accumulation of refined essence**,
**Sage-Way** is the **ultimate convergence**#43.
**Essence** gathers, **spirit** forms—
**this is the extreme**.
**Imperial decree, divine transformation**—
this is the **goal of governance**.
**Utmost**, **exhausted**—
nothing more can be added.
Thus **the teacher** *(or: **the ruler**)* **as sovereign**,
**the student** *(or: **the subject**)* **as minister**.
The **highest virtue** becomes **Emperor**,
the **next virtue** becomes **the Three Ministers**,
the **highest rank** becomes **the feudal lords**.
**High rank** is what **makes them feudal lords**.
**Changing surnames to rule**,
not **using ancestral records** *(or: **rites**)* as **sovereigns**—
they **seek uniformity in the security of goodness**.
**Yao passed rule to Shun**,
**Shun passed rule to Yu**—
this is the **Way** they used.

**Heaven and Earth’s movements** stir within the **chest**,
then **deeds are accomplished externally**;
**all things emerge and return**,
then **harmony follows without harm**.
The **Sage’s heart** has **no external law**,
yet **qi aligns with spirit**,
**spirit aligns with the Void**.
**Heaven and Earth’s vastness**, **all things’ multitude**—
their **movements, emergences, returns** all within the **chest**,
then **how could deeds fail to succeed**,
**how could things fail to prosper**?

**Opening and closing the four seasons**,
**guiding yin and yang’s shifts**,
**drowning grievances**, **clarifying things**—
*(doubtful)*
**The world** assumes it is **natural**,
**the people** say, *“This is how it is of itself.”*
This is how the **Divine Saints surpass all others**.

**Zigong** said:
*“Master Kong is Heaven—
one cannot ascend by steps.”*
**Sagehood’s root** is **spirit-pattern**,
**verified yet unseen**.
**Emotion and nature** exist,
**without action, without form**.
Thus **exceeding others is visible**,
**transcending others is not distant**.

chunks.original_text: 《南华》曰：南行者至於郢，北面而不见冥山，是何也？ 则去之远矣。 神明所以类合者也。 故神明锢结其弦， 纮者，取譬於冠。 而锢结云者，以明无危堕之患也。 类类生成，用一不穷。 或作用不穷一。 所谓仲尼神明也，小以成小，大以成大，至於山、川、乌、兽、草、木，裕如也。 影则随形，响则或作明应声，故形、声者，天地之师也。 随而应之，故曰师也。 四时之功，阴阳不能独为也。 圣王者，不失本末，故神明终始焉。 辅相导阴阳终始四时之功。 卒令八风三光之变，经或作缠气不常之故，孰不韶请或作诸都或作鄙理焉。 都之为言，总也，读如都鄙之都。 此言人保圣人，故阴阳失和，诏而请之，使总理焉。 虽然，大乱之本，实始於此。 此庚桑楚所以不释於老聃之言。 故下文云。 故神灵威明上变光， 老聃所谓上悖日月之明。 疾徐缓急中动气， 老聃所谓中堕四时之施。 煞伤毁祸下在地。 或作征下在地。 老聃所谓下烁山川之精。 故天地阴阳之受命，取象於神明之效，既已见矣。 其效如上所谓，亦已见矣。 虽然，岂遂可以无圣人之治哉？ 故下文云。 天者，气之所总出也； 所谓虹霓也，霜露也，风雨也，积气之成乎天者也。 地者，理之必然或作理然之必也。 无可无不可者，天道也。 地道则取必焉。 故圣人者，出之於天， 其道常出於天。 收之於地。 不肯出於地也。 在天地若阴阳或无阳字者#42，杜燥湿以法义，与时迁焉。 或无焉字。 若阴者以法义杜燥，若阳者以法义杜湿。 度万云：神湿则天不生水，形燥则地不生火。 三者#43，圣人或无人字存则治、亡则乱者，天失其文，地失其理也。 以是或作文知先灵， 先灵，先王之灵。 王百神者，上德执大道。 凡此者，物之长也。 及或作乃至乎祖籍之世代继之君，身虽不贤，然南面称寡犹不果亡者，其能受教乎有道之士者也。 不然而能守宗庙存国家者，未之有也。 鹖冠子卷中竟 #1《四库》本案：『一本音下缺一字； 又，声上多一「故」字疑悮』。 #2『燥』，《道藏》本原作『屎』，误。 今据文义及《四库》本改。 #3『伣』，《四库》本百子本作『视』，是。
chunks.translated_text:
The *Nanhua* [1] asks: *"When traveling southward, one reaches Ying [2].
Facing north, yet not seeing the Ming Mountains [3]—why is that?
It is because one is far removed from them.
This is how the **Divine Saints** align in kind.*

Thus, the **Divine Saints** bind and knot their **threads** [4],
**Zhuan** [5] takes analogy from the **cap** [6],
while binding and knotting the clouds [7] serves to make clear
there is no fear of **precipitous fall** [8].
Kind upon kind brings forth creation,
**using the One without exhaustion** [9].
Or, **One acts, exhausting all uses** [10].
This is what is called **Zhongni’s** [11] **Divine Luminance** [12]:
small things **prosper small things**, great things **prosper great things**,
down to **mountains, rivers, crows, beasts, grasses, and trees**—
**abundant and effortless** [13].

**Shadows** follow **forms**,
**echoes** either **arise in response to sounds** [14]—
thus, **forms and sounds** are **Heaven and Earth’s models** [15].
They follow and respond in kind,
hence they are called **models**.
The **functions of the four seasons** [16],
**yin and yang** cannot **single-handedly** fulfill [17].
The **Sage Kings** [18],
do not lose **beginning and end** [19],
thus the **Divine Luminance** **endures from start to finish** [20].
They **assist, guide, and lead** [21]
**yin and yang** in their **start-to-finish functions** [22]
and the **four seasons’ operations** [23].
**Ultimately**, the **changes of the eight winds** [24],
the **three luminaries** [25],
or the **swirling *qi* that is not constant** [26]—
who does not **revere and follow** [27]?
*"Revere"* means **to gather** [28],
read as in *dūbǐ* [29].
This says that **people** **protect** the **Sage** [30],
so when **yin and yang** lose **harmony**,
they **summon and request** [31] him
to **gather and oversee** [33].
Even so, the **root of great disorder** [34]
truly **begins here**.
This is why **Gengsang Chu** [35] **refuses to let go** of Lao Dan’s words.
Hence, the following text says:

Thus, **Divine Spirits** **radiate** with **Awe-Luminance** [36],
**Lao Dan’s** *"Awe-Luminance above"* [37] **contradicts the brightness of sun and moon** [38].
**Swift and slow, relaxed and urgent**—
**the *qi* moves within** [39].
**Lao Dan’s** *"Within, it falls from the four seasons’ application*" [40].
**Extinguishing, harming, ruining, and bringing disaster** [41]—
**below, it scatters the essence of mountains and rivers** [42].
**Lao Dan’s** *"Below, it dissipates the **vitality** of mountains and rivers*" [43].
Thus, **Heaven and Earth’s** **yin and yang** **receiving their mandate** [44],
**take their models** from the **Divine Saints’** **manifestations** [45],
which have already been **seen**.
Their **effects**, as described above,
have also been **seen**.
Even so, **can one truly dispense with the Sage’s governance** [46]?
Hence, the following text says:

**Heaven** is where **the *qi*** **collectively emerges** [47];
**rainbows**, **frost and dew**, **winds and rains**—
these are **accumulated *qi*** **forming Heaven** [48].
**Earth** is where **principles** **must necessarily** [49] **be** [50].
**Without limits, without prohibitions** [51],
this is the **Dao of Heaven** [52].
The **Dao of Earth** then **takes necessity** [53].
Thus, the **Sage** **emerges from Heaven** [54],
his **Dao** always **emerges from Heaven** [55].
**He confines it to Earth** [56].
He **does not allow it to emerge from Earth** [57].
Within **Heaven and Earth**, like **yin and yang** [58],
he **blocks dryness and dampness** [59] **with righteousness** [60],
**adapting with the times** [61].
Or, **without the word "thus"** [62],
**if yin**, he **blocks dryness with righteousness**,
**if yang**, he **blocks dampness with righteousness** [63].
**Du Wan** [64] says:
*"If **Divine Dampness** [65] arises, **Heaven** will not **generate water** [66].
If **forms become dry**, **Earth** will not **generate fire** [67].
These three** [68],
the **Sage** either **preserves** [69] **or** **loses** [70]—
**Heaven loses its *pattern***, **Earth loses its *principle*** [71].
**By this**, one **knows the former spirits** [72]—
the **former spirits**, the **spirits of the ancient kings** [73].
**The kings** who **embody all things** [74],
**hold the supreme virtue** and **grasp the Great Dao** [75].
All these are **the leaders of things** [76].
**Until** the **world of Zuji’s** [77] **descendants**,
who **inherit** the **ruling position**,
though their **bodies** are not **virtuous** [78],
yet **facing south** [79] **and claiming sovereignty** [80]
still **do not utterly perish** [81],
it is because they **can accept teachings** from **scholars of the Dao** [82].
Otherwise, **to guard ancestral temples** and **preserve the state** [83],
there has never been such a case.

[1] *Nanhua* – Likely a reference to the *Nanhua Jing* (南華經, "Scripture of the Southern Flower"), an alternative name for the *Zhuangzi* (莊子), a Daoist text.

[47] Collectively emerges (所总出) – **Gathers and issues forth**.
[48] Accumulated *qi* forming Heaven (积气之成乎天) – **Condensed *qi* manifesting as Heaven**.
[49] Must necessarily (理之必然) – **Necessarily so**.
[50] Be (或作理然之必) – **Is** (alternative phrasing: **principle’s necessity**).
[51] Without limits, without prohibitions (无可无不可) – **Unrestricted, without fixed rules**.

[54] Emerges from Heaven (出之於天) – **Origins in Heaven**.

[56] Confines it to Earth (收之於地) – **Directs it toward Earth**.
[57] Does not allow it to emerge from Earth (不肯出於地) – **Refuses to let it originate from Earth**.

[66] Generate water (生水) – **Produce or nourish water**.
[67] Generate fire (生火) – **Produce or nourish fire**.
[68] These three (三者) – **The three cosmic principles (Heaven, Earth, and the Sage’s governance)**.
[69] Preserves (存) – **Maintains or upholds**.
[70] Loses (亡) – **Fails or neglects**.

[73] Spirits of the ancient kings (先王之灵) – **The spirits of past sage-kings**.
[74] Embodies all things (王百神) – **Rules over all spirits or beings**.
[75] Hold the supreme virtue and grasp the Great Dao (上德执大道) – **Possess ultimate virtue and embody the Great Way**.
[76] Leaders of things (物之长) – **Chiefs or sovereigns of all things**.

The **Sovereign**, though lacking in personal virtue, yet still assumes the throne and proclaims kingship without utterly perishing—this is because he can receive instruction from those who follow the **Dao**. chunks.original_text: 世兵第十二 道有度数，故神明可交或作效也。 《易》曰：始作八卦，以通神明之德。 物有相胜，故水火可用也。 东西南北，故形名可信也。 有方矣，然后形名着焉。 五帝在前，三王在后，上德已衰矣，兵知俱起。 黄帝百战， 百战之数未尽闻也。 盖与炎帝战於阪泉之野三，与蚩尤战於涿鹿之野七十二，此其大略也。 蚩尤七十二，或云无二字。 尧伐有唐， 《传》云：尧佐帝挚，受封於唐，二十而登帝位。 今此云尧伐有唐，未详闻也。 伐或作代。 禹服或作伐有苗，天不变其常，地不易其则，阴阳不乱其气，生死不俛其位，三光不改其用，神明不徙其法， 善用兵者，其道如此。 得失不两张，成败不两立。 所谓贤不肖者，古今一也。 君子不惰，真人不怠#1， 怠然后解，解然后堕，故君子言堕，真人言怠。 《礼》云：三日不怠，三月不解#2。 无见久贫贱。 则据简之伊尹酒保、 保，佣保也。 太公屠牛、 《传》曰：太公少贫，卖浆，值天凉； 屠牛卖肉，值天热而肉败。 管子作革或作草，百里奚官奴， 百里奚，虞人也。 虞亡，晋主辱之，以胜穆姬，而饭牛於秦，岂此所谓官奴者乎？ 海内荒乱，立为世师，莫不天地善谋。 日月不息，乃成四时，精习象神， 《南华》曰：铁成见者惊犹鬼神。 岂谓是乎？ 孰谓能之？
chunks.translated_text:
**Scroll Twelve: "The World’s Martial Arts"**
The Dao/Way has limits and measures, hence the spirit and brilliance can be engaged or rendered effective.
*The Book of Changes* says: *"The eight trigrams were first formed to convey the virtue/power of the spirit and brilliance."*

Things have their own reciprocating strengths, hence water and fire can be utilized.
East, west, south, and north—thus the forms and names can be trusted.
Once there are fixed methods, then forms and names are firmly established.

The Five Sages came before, the Three Kings after; when the virtue/power above declines, martial arts and knowledge both arise.
The Yellow Emperor fought a hundred battles—yet the full count of his wars is unknown.
It is said he fought the Yan Emperor three times at the wilds of Bàn Quán (阪泉), and Chiyou seven and twenty times at Zhúlù (涿鹿)—these are the rough outlines.
Chiyou’s *"seven and twenty"*—some say it lacks the two characters *"无"* (without).

Yao subdued Yǒu Táng (有唐).
*The Commentary* says: *"Yao assisted Emperor Zhì, receiving the fief of Táng, and at twenty years ascended the throne."*
Now it says *"Yao subdued Yǒu Táng"*—this is unclear.
*"Subdued"* may also be read as *"replaced"* (代).

Yú’s service—some read *"subdued Yǒu Miáo"* (伐有苗)—
Heaven does not alter its constancy,
Earth does not change its norms,
Yin and Yang do not disrupt their *qi*,
Life and death do not shift their order,
The Three Luminaries do not vary their functions,
The spirit and brilliance do not abandon their laws.
Thus, the adept martial artist follows the Dao/Way in this manner.

Gain and loss do not exist in duality,
Success and failure do not stand in opposition.
What is called *"the virtuous and the unvirtuous"*—this is the same in ancient and modern times.

The gentleman does not grow weary,
The true person does not slacken#1.
Slackening leads to dissolution,
Dissolution leads to ruin—
Hence the gentleman speaks of *"ruin"*,
The true person speaks of *"slackening."*
*The Rites* say: *"Three days without slackening, three months without dissolution."*
Never does one see long-term poverty or lowliness.

Then there is the case of Yī Yǐn (伊尹), the wine steward of Jiān (简), who later became a minister;
and the case of the Duke of Tào (太公), the butcher of cattle, who later became a world teacher.
*The Commentary* says: *"The Duke of Tào was young and poor, selling milk, when the weather turned cold;
he sold meat as a butcher, but when the weather grew hot, the meat spoiled."*
Guan Zhòng made armor or grass mats,
and Bǎilǐ Xī (百里奚) served as a slave.
Bǎilǐ Xī was a man of Yú (虞)—when Yú fell, the Jin lord humiliated him, forcing him to cook meals for Mù Jī (穆姬), and later to tend cattle in Qin. Was this truly the *"slave"* spoken of?

When the world falls into chaos,
one rises as its teacher—
all act with Heaven and Earth’s sage-like counsel.
The sun and moon never cease,
thus the four seasons are perfected—
through meticulous practice and mastery of forms,
one attains the spirit’s likeness.
*The Nán Huá* (南华) says: *"The ironworker’s art astonishes the beholder like the appearance of ghosts and gods."*
Is this what is meant?

Who can say they possess such ability?

chunks.translated_text:
The spoken is not from innate ability without learning.
One must first cultivate its use,
then understand its origins.
This is what is meant by:
beginning with origins,
nurturing through nature,
fulfilling through destiny.

Tang could overthrow Jie with seventy *li*,
King Wu could subdue Zhou with a hundred *li*—
knowing one principle, no need for excess;
knowing one principle, simplicity follows.

A thousand schemes and myriad complexities,
all blending into uniformity—
when gathered under a singular essence,
they cannot differ.

The Dao of victory is not singular;
the methods of conquest are not confined to one path.
The wise calculate comprehensively—
in battle, they must prevail;
in assault, they must seize.
A sagely commander does not abandon advantage for the sake of time,
nor does a brave warrior fear death to extinguish his reputation.

Those who seek to surpass the utmost virtue
must think differently from the common crowd.
Conforming to the crowd brings sickness of the mind;
to surpass the utmost virtue is difficult indeed.

To verify the height of the Nine Heavens,
one does not walk a shortcut—
how can one reach it by asking for directions?
The Nine Heavens are fully revealed in the *Honglie Zhenjing*.
Thus, the southern realm is called the Vermilion Heaven,
the northern realm the Dark Heaven,
the central realm the Hooked Heaven, and so forth.

Therefore, loyal ministers do not prioritize themselves over their lord,
yet when isolated and abandoned,
they become suspended generals—
in open battle, the nation weakens and the people exhaust;
in city defense, they consume flesh and roast bones.
Some even boil children for food,
chopping corpses to cook.
When strategy fails,
the state is diminished, the ruler constrained,
and they become the laughingstock of the world.
Those who manage state affairs—
how can they afford to be careless?

There are indeed errors in calculation,
and there are trials—
trials may fail through negligence,
encounters may fail through overrefinement;
what matters is striking the balance.
Thus, Cao Mǐ served as Ru’s general,
fighting three battles against Qi and losing a thousand *li*.
Had Caozi not considered the aftermath,
and instead died by his own hand,
he would have been no more than a defeated general, a captured commander.
But Caozi reasoned:
a defeated general is not courageous;
a diminished state and ruined name are not wise;
dying while the lord is in peril is not loyal.
Those who die for others cannot prolong another’s life,
so he withdrew to advise the Ru lord.

When Duke Huan assembled the feudal lords,
Caozi seized the duke by the throne with a single sword,
his expression unchanging, his words unflinching.
The lost lands were recovered in a day,
shaking the world, startling the neighbors,
and his name echoed through the ages.
Had he clung to petty resentment,
great deeds would not have been accomplished.
Thus, Caozi abandoned transient anger
to establish a lifelong legacy,
discarding minor shame
to earn renown for generations.
Hence, Caozi understood the times,
and the Ru lord knew his men.

Ju Xin served as Yan’s general,
fought against Zhao, and lost the battle.
Ju Xin took his own life,
and Yan lost five cities.
He opened the door to disaster for himself,
died while endangering his lord,
and his name and reputation perished—
this was failure,
a strategy without foresight.
It was not a lack of ability,
but rather a disregard for preserving life.
Though Cao Mǐ’s actions coincided with Guan Zhong’s era,
he did not seek short-term gratification
but instead ensured Qi’s credibility among the feudal lords,
thus fulfilling his reputation.

As for Li Ling’s surrender,
he sought to repay Han
but ultimately saw his entire clan exterminated,
and the men of Longxi regarded it as shame.
How could Caozi’s bold action be considered ordinary?
Much less for a conqueror’s deeds.

As for those of *Wangde*’s virtue,
whose sincerity and clarity are innate,
they would not condemn Mǐ to death in Ru’s lands—
what is there to praise in that?

Those who attain the Dao strive to avoid great failure;
ordinary people strive for minor virtues.
Minor virtues accumulate into many vices,
many vices prevent the accumulation of virtue,
and without accumulation, misfortune follows—
some say many vices bring many misfortunes.
Misfortune brings turbidity,
turbidity brings ignorance.
Excessive desires lead to narrowness,
narrowness breeds many worries,
many worries bring turbidity,
turbidity brings ignorance.
Desires and vices—
these are what obscure wisdom.

The powerless are shamed,
and shame is disgrace.
Thus, Ju Xin could sever his fate,
yet the Yan king failed to discern talent.

In ancient times, skilled warriors
mustered armies in unison,
arrayed them according to the Five Phases,
fought with the Five Notes,
pointed to the celestial pole,
aligned with the divine,
and from this, all things took form—
using one principle without exhaustion.
The enlightened established the method,
the subtle Dao was put into practice,
advancing and retreating in harmony—
*harmony* means not overstepping.
Combining with Heaven and Earth,
emerging from substance to touch emptiness,

chunks.original_text: 吴奔东南，亚夫使备西北，盖知此矣。 禽将破军，发如镞或作鍭矢，动如雷霆，暴疾梼虚，殷若坏墙， 殷，坏声也。 执急节短， 《孙子兵法》曰：其执险，其节短。 用不缦缦，避我所死，就吾所生，趋吾所时，援或作授吾所胜，故士不折北，兵不困穷。 得此道者，驱用市人，乘流以逝，或作游。 与道翱翔。 翱翔授取，锢据或作豫坚守； 呼吸镇一作推，或作损移， 镇，不移也。 与时更为。 一先一后，音律相奏； 或作奉。 一右一左，道无不可。 受数於天，定位於地，成名於人。 彼时之至，安可复还？ 或作复还至。 复，反复也。 还，回还也。 安可控搏#13？ 控，引也。 搏，持也。 复还言不可御，控搏言不可止。 天地不倚，错以待能。 度数相使，阴阳相攻，死生相摄，气威相灭，虚实相因，得失浮或作得失相浮县。 浮县，言无定也。 兵以势胜， 兵法曰：如转圆石於千仞之山者，势也。 时不常使，蚤晚绌赢，反相殖生。 变化无穷，何可胜言？ 水激则旱，矢激则远，精神回薄，振荡相转，迟速有命， 有命，一作言息，又作止息。 必中三伍#14。 合散消息，孰识其时？ 至人遗物，遗物，或作不遗。 独或作动与道俱，纵驱委命，与时往来。 盛衰死生，孰识其期？ 俨然至湛，孰知其尤？ 祸乎福之所倚，福乎祸之所伏，祸与福如纠纆。 此言祸福相为表裹，执如索绹纆索也。 三合曰纠。 浑沌错纷，其状若一，交解形状，孰知其则？ 芴芒无貌， 貌，或为根。 唯圣人而后决其意，或作能决其意。 斡流迁徙，固无休息。 小休曰息。 终则有始，孰知其极？ 一目之罗，不可以得雀， 太疏#15故也。 笼中之乌，空窥不出。 太密故也。 众人唯唯，安定祸福？ 忧喜聚门，吉凶同域， 庆者在堂，吊者在门。 失反为得，成反为败。 吴大兵强，夫差以困； 越栖会稽，勾践霸世。 达人大观，乃见其可。 可，或作苛。 椭枋一术，奚足以游？ 椭，读如隋銎之隋。 枋，读如方变之方。 夫天下之事，百出要以百变应之。 而今隋方一术，则岂足游於变通之会哉？ 往古来今，事孰无邮？ 邮，置邮也。 行者过之而巳，故事之过者为邮。 舜有不孝，尧有不慈，文王桎桔，管仲拘囚。 坱轧□垠，□垠，或作葬云。 孰□得之？ 此言大钧播物，坱轧无垠，皆在垆□之内，孰□得之。 至得无私，泛泛乎若不系之舟， 任之而已。 能者以济，不能者以覆。 天不可与谋，地不可与虑。 圣人捐物，从理与舍。 众人域域， 域域，浅狭之貌。 迫於嗜欲。 小知立趋，好恶自惧。 夸者死权，自贵矜容。 一本自矜容下云徇名终身谋奈，无列士以下两句。 《诗》曰：垂带悸兮是也。 列士徇名，贪夫徇财。 以身逐物曰徇。 至博不给，给，或作结。 统之无要，则虽博乃更不给。 何则？ 至道常约故也。

When an army is about to break, its movements are swift as arrows loosed or crossbow bolts, thunderous as thunder and lightning, fierce as a collapsing wall. The soldiers grasp their weapons tightly, their stances rigid—*The Art of War* says: *"When their grip is firm, their stance is short."* Their actions are unyielding, avoiding my death ground, seeking my life ground, advancing when the time is ripe, seizing opportunities—*or* lending strength to my advantages. Thus, the soldiers never falter in retreat, the army never finds itself in dire straits.

He who masters this Dao can drive even common folk like cattle, ride the current as if gliding—*or* soar with the Dao. Soaring and seizing, securing and defending—*or* preparing defenses; breathing in and out—*or* adjusting and shifting—*stillness without movement.* Aligning with the rhythm of time, one step forward, one step back, like musical notes in harmony—*or* in service. One to the right, one to the left—*the Dao knows no impossibility.*

Receiving measure from Heaven, establishing position on Earth, attaining form through humanity. When the moment arrives, how can it be undone?—*or* how can its return be forced? *Return* means reversal; *stillness* means withdrawal. How can it be restrained or grasped? *Restrained* means drawn back; *grasped* means held fast. *Stillness* speaks of the ungovernable; *restraint* speaks of the unchecked.

Heaven and Earth do not lean—*they shift in response to ability.* Measures interact, yin and yang contend, death and life constrain, qi and power annihilate, emptiness and substance depend on each other, gain and loss drift—*or* float indeterminately. *Floating indeterminately* means without fixed form. War is won by advantage—*The Art of War says:* *"Like rolling a round stone down a thousand-zhang mountain, that is advantage."* Time does not always favor one side; early or late, one may falter while the other thrives, each generating the other’s strength. Change is boundless—how can it be fully spoken?

Water struck becomes dry; an arrow struck flies farther. Spirit vibrates and thins, oscillating in turn. Slowness and speed are fated—*fated* means *halted* or *ceased.* It must strike the three ranks. *Three ranks* refers to the three divisions of an army. Gathering and dispersing, ebbing and flowing—who can know the moment?

The perfected transcends things—*or* does not cling to them—moving alone with the Dao, unrestrained, abandoning fate, coming and going with time. Rise and decline, life and death—who can know their measure? Solemn and profound, who can fathom their depth? Calamity is the reverse of fortune; fortune is the reverse of calamity. Calamity and fortune are intertwined like twisted cords. *Three strands twisted together make a cord.* Chaos and confusion—its form is singular, yet shapes dissolve and reform. Who knows their pattern?

Without form or boundary—*or* root—only the Sage can discern its intent—*or* is able to discern its intent. Flowing and shifting, it never rests. *A brief pause is called rest.* Ending leads to beginning—who knows its limit?

A net with one eye cannot catch a sparrow—*too sparse.* A bird in a cage only peers out—*too dense.* The common crowd murmurs in agreement—how can they settle fortune and calamity? Joy and sorrow gather at the gate; good and ill share the same domain. *Mourners at the door while guests feast in the hall.* Loss becomes gain; success becomes failure.

Wu had mighty armies and strong forces—yet King Fu Zhi was brought low. Yue took refuge in Kuaiji—yet King Gou Jian became a hegemon. The enlightened observer sees the truth. *Truth* or *harshness.* A single technique—how can it suffice for roaming?

*Elliptical and square*—what use are they for adaptability? *Elliptical* is read like *Sui Dù’s* "Sui"; *square* like *Fāng Biàn’s* "Fāng." The affairs of the world demand a hundred responses, each varying to meet a hundred changes. Yet now, clinging to one technique—how can it suffice in the realm of adaptability?

From ancient times to now, what event lacks its counterpart? *Counterpart* means *a station for relaying messages.* Travelers pass through it without pause; thus, past events are called *counterparts.* Shun had unfilial conduct; Yao lacked tenderness. King Wen was bound in chains; Guan Zhong was imprisoned. Towering and vast—*or* buried in clouds—who can grasp it?

This speaks of the Great Pivot dispersing things—towering and vast without boundary, all within the *Lǔ* vessel—who can grasp it? The perfected has no partiality, drifting like an untethered boat—*simply yielding.* The capable are saved; the incapable are destroyed. Heaven cannot be schemed with; Earth cannot be plotted against. The Sage abandons things, follows nature, and lets go.

The common crowd is confined—*confined* means *narrow and shallow*—pressured by desires. The slightly wise rush to act, fearing good and evil. The arrogant die by their power, boasting in self-importance—*or* spending their lives scheming for fame. *One version omits:* "The scholar pursues fame; the greedy man pursues wealth. To chase after things with one’s body is called *serving* them."

The most expansive lacks sufficiency—*or* is bound. Governing without a key, even vastness becomes insufficient. Why? The Supreme Dao is ever concise.

The wise know time—what shame is there in that?
They feel no guilt, yet do nothing wrong.
The unworthy are bound by convention—*or, as one version reads, "enveloped by custom"*—
while the virtuous vie for influence in their age.
Knowledge is but the tool of contention.
Fame is but the clash of reputations.
*One version reads "clings to trifles," another "clings to the vulgar,"*
and yet another, *"clings to petty matters"*—*both versions imply "like a bitter herb or thorn."*

What need is there to doubt?
When deeds are done and rewards sought, what need is there to boast?
This speaks of harmony with the Way and its opposite—
there is no cause for joy or sorrow.

Thousands of words and ten thousand arguments—
in the end, what praise is given?
This means that reason is fully exhausted above,
yet even if their verbose arguments pile up to thousands or ten thousands,
still they must be judged by this.

Gōu Jiàn lacked office,
Gōu Jiàn once served as a subject to Wú.
Two kingdoms remained unsettled;
Wén Wáng lacked confinement,
*yet he was confined in Měilǐ*.
Wǔ Wáng lacked rectitude—*or, as one version reads, "did not hold to rectitude"*—
Guān Zhòng suffered no humiliation,
yet his name was not equated with the great virtuous,
and his deeds were not compared to the Three Sovereigns#16.
The *tāng* face is complete.

*Complete knowledge is the thirteenth chapter.*
Heaven is vast yet can be known,
Earth is great yet can be governed.
How can all things be at ease?
How can human nature be without taking?
Bó Yí and Shū Qí could prevent theft,
yet they could not stop people from harboring intentions against themselves.
*Can one be certain of meeting only adversity?*
Shēn Tú Dì.

chunks.original_text: 殷之末世枯槁者也。 以为世涵浊不可居，故负石自投於河，不知水中之乱有逾甚者。 德之盛，山无径迹，泽无桥梁，不相往来，舟车不通。 何者？ 其民犹赤子也， 《老子》曰：含德之厚，比於赤子。 男曰赤子，女曰婴儿。 有知者不以相欺役也，有力者不以相臣主也。 是以鸟鹊之巢可俯而窥也，伶，麋鹿群居可从而系也。 乌鹊性猜瞿，麋庇性惊决，放此主言之。 至世之衰，父子相图，兄弟相疑。 夫父子，天性也； 兄弟，天伦也。 恩信素足，非自外至。 故跟市人之足则辞以脱悞，兄则以妪，大亲而已矣。 令德下衰而至於父子相犹、兄弟相□者，岂其性固异於古也哉？ 盖治之之过也。 何者？ 其化薄而出於相以有为也。 此言不能相与於无相与#17，相为於无相为，故其弊至此。 郭象曰：夫体天地、冥变化者，虽手足异任、五藏殊管，未尝相与而百节同和，斯相与於无相与也； 未尝相为而表裹俱济，斯相为於无相为也。 若乃役其心志以恤手足，运其殷肱以营五藏，则相营愈笃而内外愈困矣。 盖知此也。 故为者败之，治者乱之，败则傰， 傰，党也。 乱则阿，阿则理废，佣则义不立。 尧传舜以天下，故好义者以为尧智，其好利者以为尧愚。 汤、武放弒利其子，好义者以为无道， 此言何谓也？ 若予所学则唯好义者以为有道。 而好利之人以为贤。 为或无为字彼世不传贤，故有放君。 君好傰阿，故有弒主。 夫放弒之所加，亡国之所在，吾未见便乐或作见其便乐而安处之者也。 夫处危以妄安，循哀以损乐，是故国有无服之丧、无军之兵，可以先见也。 是故箕子逃 逃，逃祸也，非谓逃而去之。 孔子曰：微子去之，箕子为之奴。 而搏裘牧#18， 《宋世家》曰：南宫万杀愍公于蒙泽，大夫裘牧闻之，以兵造公门，万搏牧，牧齿着门死。 即其事也。 商容拘而蹇叔哭。
chunks.translated_text:
The decline of the Yin dynasty was marked by withering and decay.
He deemed the world’s corruption too deep to endure,
so he bore a stone and cast himself into the river—
yet he failed to see that the chaos beneath was even worse.

When virtue flourished,
mountains lacked paths, marshes lacked bridges—
no travel between them, no passage by boat or cart.
Why?
Because its people remained as pure as infants.
*As Laozi says:*
*"Thick with virtue, like an infant."*
Males were called *chīzǐ*, females *yīng’ér*.
The wise did not deceive or enslave one another,
the strong did not lord over others as rulers.
Thus, the nests of crows and magpies could be glimpsed from below,
and the timid deer and startled elk could be easily captured.
*Crows and magpies are naturally suspicious,*
*deer and elk are naturally skittish*—
this explains the saying.

Yet when the age declined,
fathers plotted against sons, brothers doubted brothers.
Fathers and sons are by nature,
brothers by kinship—
trust and sincerity were innate, not imposed from without.
Thus, even when striking a stranger’s foot, one would feign stumbling,
and when striking a brother’s, one would feign hitting an old woman—
such was the extent of their kinship.
But when virtue waned to the point where fathers and sons became rivals,
brothers turned against one another—
was this because their nature had fundamentally changed from antiquity?
No, it was the fault of governance.
For when cultivation grew shallow and reliance on artificial means took hold,
they could not coexist without strife,
nor act without scheming—
and so their ruin reached this point.

Guo Xiang remarked:
*"Those who embody Heaven and Earth, who subtly transform without effort—
though hands and feet have distinct roles,
and the five viscera govern differently,
they never conspire to disrupt harmony,
yet all limbs move in unison—
this is to coexist without contrivance.
They never scheme to aid one another,
yet the outer and inner both thrive—
this is to act without scheming.
But if one forces the mind to labor for the limbs,
or strains the arms to nourish the viscera,
then the more they strive, the more exhausted they become within and without.
This is the truth."*

Thus, those who *do* bring ruin,
those who *govern* bring chaos.
Chaos leads to factionalism—*fǎn*—
factionalism leads to flattery—*ē*—
flattery undermines principle,
and servility erodes righteousness.

When Yao passed the Mandate to Shun,
the virtuous saw it as Yao’s wisdom,
but the self-interested saw it as folly.
Tang and Wu abandoned their sons for profit—
the virtuous condemned them as unprincipled.
*But why?*
If my teachings are correct,
then only the virtuous would deem them righteous,
while the self-interested would call them wise.
*For* in that age, the worthy were not transmitted,
so there were exiled rulers.
When rulers favored factionalism and flattery,
there were regicides.
Where exiles and regicides struck,
there the state perished—
I have never seen one who, seeing the danger,
found comfort in false security,
or, clinging to sorrow, diminished joy.

Thus, states could face mourning without ritual,
warfare without soldiers—
such outcomes could be foreseen.

Hence, Ji Zi fled—
*not to escape, but to avert calamity.*
Confucius said:
*"Miczi departed, Ji Zi became his slave."*
Yet there was also *Bóqiú Mù*—
*as the Song Genealogy records:*
*"Nan Gong Wan slew Duke Min at Mengze Marsh.
The minister Bóqiú Mù, hearing of it,
led soldiers to the duke’s gate.
Wan attacked Mù, who died with his teeth lodged in the door."*
This was the reality.

Shang Rong was imprisoned,
and Shěn Shù wept.

chunks.original_text: 蹇叔，秦臣也。 穆公袭郑，蹇叔哭之。 昔之登高者，下人代之□，或作殪。 □，怖也。 手足为之汗出， 怖故为之汗濡。 而上人或无人字乃始抟折枝而趋操木#19， 言傍观者为之惊惧，而登高之人虽危莫知焉，乃始抟而折枝，趋而操木。 止之者僇， 止之使勿尔者，覆受僇焉。 凡此以况处危忘安，而谏者蒙辱之义。 是故天下寒心而人主孤立。 今世之处侧者皆乱臣也，其智足以使主不达，其言足以滑政，其朋党足以相育於利害。 昔汤用伊尹，周用太公，秦用百里， 百里奚也。 楚用申麃， 申包胥也。 齐用管子，此数大夫之所以高世者，皆亡国之忠臣所以死也。 此言古之人其才一也，或以高世，由亦或以死者#20，所遇之君异也。 是观之#21，非其智能难与也，乃其时命者不可及也。 此言伊、吕、申、管之才，人非莫及也，而箕、裘之徒卒以杀辱者，无其时命故也。 唯无如是， 无其时命。
chunks.translated_text:
Shěn Shù was a subject of Qin. When Duke Mu of Qin attacked Zheng, Shěn Shù wept for it.

In ancient times, those who climbed high places—
when others below took their place,
some wrote *yù* (殪), meaning *fright* (怖).
The hands and feet would sweat from fear,
and those above, though trembling, knew no dread,
yet only then would they clutch and break branches,
hasten and grasp wood.

To stop them was to suffer mutilation,
and those who tried to halt them—
they themselves bore the punishment.

All this illustrates those in peril who forget security,
while advisors suffer disgrace.

Thus, the world grows cold-hearted,
and rulers stand alone.

Nowadays, those in precarious positions are all traitors—
their wit suffices to mislead their lords,
their words to undermine governance,
their factions to nurture mutual gain and harm.

In the past, Tang used Yi Yin,
Zhou used Tai Gong,
Qin used Bai Li—Bai Li Delin.
Chu used Shen Bao Xu,
Qi used Guan Zhong.

These great ministers—
by whom the age was elevated—
were all loyal subjects of ruined states,
who died for them.

This shows that ancient talents were equal:
some rose to prominence,
others died—
it depended on the ruler they encountered.

To observe this:
it was not their wisdom or ability that failed,
but the fate of their times that could not be reached.

This speaks of the talents of Yi, Lü, Shen, and Guan—
no one was beyond their reach—
yet Ji Zi and Bóqiú Mù met with death and humiliation,
for they lacked the right fate.

Only thus—
only thus—
was their fate denied.

chunks.original_text: 时有所至而求，或作袁，又或作表。 有君无臣，故虽时有所至而上求焉。 时有所至而辞， 有臣无君，故虽时有所至而下辞焉。 命有所至而阖，或作合。 阖，犹辞也。 命有所至而辟。 或作阙。 辟，犹求也。 贤不必得时也，不肖不必失命也，是故贤者守时而不肖者守命。 守命，犹委命也。 今世非无舜之行也，不知尧之故也； 非无汤、武之事也，不知伊尹、太公之故也。 费仲、恶来得辛纣之利，而不知武王之伐之也； 比干、子胥好忠谏，而不知其主之煞之也。 费仲、恶来者可谓知心矣，而不知事； 比干、子胥者可谓知事矣，而不知心。 圣人者，必两备而后能究一世。 兵政第十四 庞子问鹖冠子曰：用兵之法，天之、地之、人之，赏以劝战，罚以必众。 或作恐众。 五者已图，然九夷用之而胜不必者，其故何也？ 得其战矣，未得其所以战也，故九夷用之而不必胜。 语曰：以书御者，不尽马之情。 此之谓也。 故曰：夫子驰亦驰，夫子趋亦趋，夫子奔逸绝尘，而回瞠若乎其后。 其近是乎？ 鹖冠子曰：物有生， 生，犹化也。 故金木水火未用而相制。 此言前期而胜也。 子独不见夫闭关乎？ 立而倚之，则妇人揭之。 或作易褐之上。 仆而措之，则不择性而能举其中。 句。 若操其端，则虽选士不能绝地。 关尚一身而轻重异之者，执使之然也。 夫以关言之，则物有而执在矣。 九夷用之而胜不必者，其不达物生者也。 此言不达事变物化，故辄败北。 《素问》曰：物生之谓化，物极之谓变。 若达物生者，五尚一也耳。 庞子曰：以五为一，奈何？ 鹖冠子曰：天不能以早为晚，地不能以高为下，人不能以男为女，赏不能劝不胜任， 金帛在前，不能使尪者负。 罚不能必不或无不字可。 斧钺在后，不能使哑者呜。 庞子曰：取功，奈何？ 鹖冠子曰：天不能使人，人不能使天。 因或作固物之然，而穷达存焉。 之二也，在权在埶。 在权故生财有过富，在执故用兵有过胜。 财之生也，力之於地，顺之於天； 兵之胜也，顺之於道，合之於人。 其弗知者，以逆为顺，以患为利。 以逆为顺，故其财贫； 以患为利，故其兵禽。 昔之知时者与道证，或作澄#22。 弗知者危神明。 道之所亡，或作厈。 神明之败，何物可以留其创？ 留，犹止也。 使创不伸曰留。 故曰：道乎道乎，或作道道乎。 与神明相保乎。 庞子曰：何如而相保？ 鹖冠子曰：贤生圣， 贤上生圣。 圣生道，道生法，法生神， 一阴一阳之谓道。 制而用之谓之法。 利用出入、民咸用之，谓之神。 神生明。 神下生明。 神明者，正之末也。 偏生合，公生明，诚信生神。 故曰正之末也。 末或无末字受之本，是故相保。 学问第十五 庞子问鹖冠子曰：圣人之问服师也#23， 服，事也。 亦有终始乎？ 抑其拾或作舍。 下同诵记辞，阖棺而止乎？ 鹖冠子曰：始於初问，终於九道。 若不闻九道之解，拾诵记辞，阖棺而止，以何定乎？ 此言非独白纷如也，虽至阖棺而止，尚不足以定之也。 故所贵乎问学者，岂诵说之云乎？ 在於得书之体，得言之解。 庞子曰：何谓九道？ 鹖冠子曰：一曰道德，二曰阴阳，三曰法令，四曰天官，五曰神征，六曰伎艺，七曰人情，八曰械器，九曰处兵。 庞子曰：愿闻九道之事。
chunks.translated_text:
When the **Way** reaches its moment, one may **seek**—
or act as **Yuan**,
or as **Biao**.

When there is a ruler but no minister,
even when the **Way** reaches its moment,
the minister **seeks** from above.

When the **Way** reaches its moment, one may **withdraw**—
when there is a minister but no ruler,
even when the **Way** reaches its moment,
the minister **withdraws** below.

When **fate** reaches its moment, one may **close**—
or act as **He**.

*Close* is like *withdraw*.
When **fate** reaches its moment, one may **open**—
or act as *Que*.
*Open* is like *seek*.

The virtuous do not necessarily meet their time,
the unvirtuous do not necessarily lose their fate—
thus, the virtuous **guard the Way**,
while the unvirtuous **guard fate**.
*Guard fate* is like *entrusting to fate*.

In this age, there are those with Shun’s conduct,
yet they do not know the reason for Yao’s rise;
there are those with Tang and Wu’s deeds,
yet they do not know the reason for Yi Yin and Tai Gong’s rise.

Fei Zhong and E Lai gained from Xin Zhe’s favor,
yet they did not know that Wu Wang would conquer him;
Ji Gan and Wu Zixu loved loyal admonition,
yet they did not know their lords would kill them.

Fei Zhong and E Lai could be said to know the heart,
yet they did not know the circumstances;
Ji Gan and Wu Zixu could be said to know the circumstances,
yet they did not know the heart.

The sage must possess both—
only then can they master an age.

---
**Chapter Fourteen: On Warfare**

Pangzi asked Lüguanzi:
*"The laws of warfare—
heaven’s, earth’s, and humanity’s—
reward to encourage battle,
punish to ensure the multitude.
Some say ‘terrify the multitude.’

When these five are applied,
yet the Nine Barbarians use them and victory is not certain—
why is this so?

They have obtained the battle,
but not the reason for battle—
thus, the Nine Barbarians use them and victory is not certain.*

As the saying goes:
*'One who drives a chariot by the book
does not fully grasp the horse’s nature.'*

This is what is meant.

Thus it is said:
*'When the master gallops, the horse gallops;
when the master trots, the horse trots;
when the master races and leaves dust behind,
the horse gazes back in bewilderment.'*

Is this not so?

Lüguanzi said:
*'Things have their nature—
*nature*, like *transformation*.
Thus, before they are used, metal, wood, water, and fire restrain one another.
This is called *prevailing before the appointed time*.*

Have you not seen the gate?
If you stand and lean against it,
even a woman can lift it.
If you kneel and place it,
it can be raised without regard to strength.
If you grasp its handle,
even a chosen warrior cannot sever the ground.

Though the gate is but one body,
its weight differs by how it is held—
this is because the method determines it.

Speaking of the gate,
its nature is in the hand that holds it.
The Nine Barbarians use it and victory is not certain—
because they do not grasp the nature of things.

As the *Su Wen* says:
*'The generation of things is called transformation,
their extreme is called change.'*

If one grasps the generation of things,
the five become one.

Pangzi said:
*'How can the five become one?'*

Lüguanzi said:
*'Heaven cannot make early into late,
earth cannot make high into low,
humanity cannot make male into female,
rewards cannot encourage the unworthy—
gold and silk before them cannot make the aged carry them,
punishments cannot ensure the guilty—
axes and blades behind them cannot make the mute speak.*

Pangzi said:
*'How then does one achieve success?'*

Lüguanzi said:
*'Heaven cannot command humanity,
humanity cannot command heaven.
Follow the nature of things,
and success or ruin lies within.
This is the second principle—
it lies in *authority* and *control*.

It lies in authority, so wealth may exceed abundance;
it lies in control, so warfare may exceed victory.
The generation of wealth
depends on strength upon the earth,
harmony with heaven;
victory in war
depends on harmony with the **Way**,
unity with humanity.

Those who do not know this
take disorder for harmony,
disaster for advantage.
Taking disorder for harmony,
their wealth becomes poverty;
taking disaster for advantage,
their armies are captured.

In the past, those who knew the times
harmonized with the **Way**,
or *clarified* it.
Those who did not know it
endangered their spirit and clarity.
When the **Way** is lost,
or *oppressed*,
and spirit and clarity are ruined—
what can stay the wound?
*Stay* means to halt its spread.

Thus it is said:
*'Oh **Way**, oh **Way**—
preserve spirit and clarity together.'*

Pangzi said:
*'How does one preserve them together?'*

Lüguanzi said:
*The virtuous generate the sage,
the virtuous above generate the sage.
The sage generates the **Way**,
the **Way** generates law,
law generates spirit,
one yin and one yang—this is the **Way**.
To regulate and apply it is called *law*.
Its beneficial use in entering and exiting,
all people employing it—this is *spirit*.
Spirit generates clarity.
Spirit below generates clarity.
Spirit and clarity—
this is the end of *rectification*.
Partiality generates unity,
publicness generates clarity,
sincerity and trust generate spirit.
Thus it is said: *This is the end of rectification.*
The end may have no end—
thus, they preserve each other.*

---
**Chapter Fifteen: On Learning**

Pangzi asked Lüguanzi:
*"When the sage studies under a teacher,
does he have a beginning and end?
Or does he merely collect and recite,
closing the coffin and stopping there?"*

Lüguanzi said:
*"The beginning is in the first question,
the end is in the Nine **Paths**.
If one does not hear the resolution of the Nine **Paths**,
merely collecting and reciting,
closing the coffin and stopping—
how can one be certain?

This is not just about white and black confusion—
even when the coffin is closed and study ends,
it is still insufficient to determine truth.

Thus, what is precious in studying
is not merely reciting words—
it lies in grasping the body of the text,
understanding the meaning of speech."*

Pangzi said:
*"What are the Nine **Paths**?"*

Lüguanzi said:
*"First, **Dao** and virtue;
second, yin and yang;
third, laws and orders;
fourth, celestial officials;
fifth, divine omens;
sixth, arts and skills;
seventh, human nature;
eighth, tools and instruments;
ninth, military strategy."*

Pangzi said:
*"I wish to hear of the Nine **Paths**."*

chunks.original_text: 鹖冠子曰：道德者，操行，所以为素也。 素如献素之素。 道德，操行之本，故曰素也。 阴阳者，分数，所以观气变也。 《周官》保章氏云：以星土，以云物，以十有二岁，以十有二风，占天地之灾祥。 法令者，主道治乱，国之命也。 天官者，表仪祥兆，下之应也。 此言学问之序。 道德已明而阴阳次之，阴阳已明而法令次之； 三者备矣，然后可以言治矣。 天官，冢宰是也。 百官取揆，故曰表仪。 造始而已，故曰祥兆。 此以静唱，彼以动和，故曰下之应也。 神征者，风采光景，所以序怪也。 《祭义》所谓其气发扬于上，为昭明煮蒿凄怆。 此百物之精也，神之着也。 伎艺者，如胜同任，或为住。 所以出无独异也。 《周官》六德则异之以智、仁、圣、义、忠、和，六艺则同之以礼、乐、射、御、书、数。 人情者，小大、愚知、贤不肖，雄俊豪英相万也。 械器者，假乘焉，或作马。 世用国备也。 处兵者，威柄所持，立不败或作取之地也。 九道形心，谓之有灵， 形，着见也。 后能见变而命之， 物至能名。 或曰：奇见异闻为变。 《列子》曰：大禹行而见之，伯益知而名之。 盖此类也。 因其所为而定之。
chunks.translated_text:
Lüguanzi said:
*"**Dao** and virtue are the conduct and principles by which one cultivates a foundation—
the foundation as clear as the offering of unblemished silk.
**Dao** and virtue are the root of conduct,
thus they are called the foundation.

Yin and yang are the divisions and harmonies
by which one observes the changes of **qi**.
The *Zhou Officials* states: ‘The Preserver of Chapters [observes] by stars and soil,
by clouds and phenomena,
by the twelve years and twelve winds,
to foretell the calamities and auspices of Heaven and Earth.’
Laws and orders are the means by which one governs **Dao**, restraining chaos and maintaining order—
the lifeblood of the state.
Celestial officials are the signs and portents of ritual propriety,
the responses of the people below.
This is the order of learning.

When **Dao** and virtue are made clear, then yin and yang follow,
and when yin and yang are made clear, then laws and orders follow;
once these three are complete,
only then can one speak of governance.

Celestial officials refer to the Grand Steward [冢宰].
All officials derive their measures from him,
thus they are called ‘signs of ritual propriety.’
He initiates the beginning,
thus they are called ‘auspicious portents.’
For he governs with stillness while others respond with action,
thus they are called ‘the people’s response.’

Divine omens are the majestic presence and radiant aura
by which one categorizes the extraordinary.
As the *Rites of Sacrifice* says:
‘When their **qi** ascends and shines above,
it becomes the manifest brilliance of *Zhaomíng* [昭明],
the sorrowful lament of *Zhúhāo* [煮蒿],
a chilling desolation.’
This is the essence of all things,
the manifestation of the divine.

Arts and skills are like the *Shèngtóng Rèn* [胜同任]—
some dwell in harmony, others in distinction.
They reveal what is singular and unique without repetition.
The *Zhou Officials* states:
‘The Six Virtues distinguish by wisdom, benevolence, sagacity, righteousness, loyalty, and harmony,
while the Six Arts harmonize by ritual, music, archery, charioteering, calligraphy, and mathematics.’

Human nature is the vast array of small and great,
foolish and wise,
virtuous and unworthy,
heroic and brilliant—
all the myriad dispositions of the people.

Tools and instruments are aids for travel—
some serve as carriages, others as steeds.
They are the implements the world uses and the state must possess.

Military strategy is the grasp of power and authority,
the establishment of an unassailable position—
or the seizing of advantageous ground.
The Nine **Paths** embody the mind,
and when embodied, they are said to have spirit.
*Form* [形] is the visible manifestation.
Later, one can perceive changes and name them,
for when things arrive, one can name them.

Some say: ‘The strange and the unusual are called changes.’
The *Liezi* states:
‘Great Yu acted upon them and saw them,
while Bo Yi understood them and named them.’
This is of the same kind.
One follows what they do to determine them."*
